Response.BaseQuestion: Oral Cancer Drug Overview
Response.Content:
Welcome to our guide on oral cancer drugs. When people think of chemotherapy, they usually think of going to a hospital or clinic and being connected to an intravenous or I-V drip or getting an injection. But now, more and more cancer patients are being treated with oral chemotherapy drugs -- cancer medications that you take by mouth, just like most other medications.
These oral cancer drugs have many benefits. Although just as powerful, oral cancer drugs don't require needles like IV cancer medications or injections. And, they can be taken at home, so there is less time spent traveling to and from clinics.
So, rather than having a healthcare provider give you the medications in a clinic, you will be taking these medications yourself and will have to follow the directions for taking them very carefully. These drugs are not just ordinary pills. They are powerful medications. Oral cancer drugs require special handling and it's important that you understand your medications so you can follow your treatment plan, manage any side effects and report them to your healthcare provider when necessary.
That's why we're here today, to help you learn about your oral cancer drugs so that you can get the most out of your treatment while keeping yourself and your loved ones safe.
Are you ready to get started?

Response.BaseQuestion: Six Important Facts about Oral Cancer Drugs
Response.Content:
Okay, here are 6 very important things you should know about oral cancer drugs: First, oral cancer drugs are just as strong and just as effective as the I-V or injected drugs you would get at a clinic or hospital.
Second, because they are such powerful drugs, it is very important that you take your medication exactly as prescribed. If you don't, your treatment may not be as effective and you may have worse side effects than expected. We'll talk about some important tips to help you stay on track with your medication so you get the best treatment possible.
Third, almost all patients on oral cancer drugs will have side effects. It is important that the side effects be managed, not only because they can affect your quality of life, but also because they can interfere with your treatment. Do not take any physical symptoms you may have lightly. Side effects need to be reported to your healthcare provider because they can be serious and even life threatening. In this program, we'll talk about the most common side effects, give you guidance on how to manage them, and discuss when to call your healthcare provider or when to get emergency help.
Fourth, oral cancer drugs can be harmful if they are not properly handled. People who have cancer and are taking these drugs should know what steps to take to keep themselves and their loved ones safe. People who don't have cancer need to avoid coming in contact with the drugs and the body fluids of people taking the drugs. Oral cancer medications should always be kept away from children and pets, and pregnant women should not handle them. We'll go over the necessary precautions you need to take to keep everyone safe.
Fifth, like many other medications, oral cancer drugs can have drug and food interactions so we'll talk about how to find out what medications or foods you should avoid.
And lastly, in the past, you would see your healthcare team every time you received medication; but now, because you're taking oral cancer drugs at home, it's important to stay in touch with your healthcare team on a regular basis to let them know how you're doing. Always call your healthcare team if you have a fever over 100.4 degrees Fahrenheit, or if you have trouble breathing, bloody stool, chest pain, or are vomiting despite taking anti-nausea medications.
This might seem a little overwhelming, there is a lot to learn. This program is designed so that you can find the information you need right now, then come back again later to learn more. You can ask your own questions at any time just by typing them in. Or you can use the links to the left to explore the topics that you're interested in. When you ask a question, we'll suggest other topics you might find interesting, in the Related Questions area to the right. During the program, we'll refer to additional links and documents that will be listed in the Resources Area at the top of the page.
Remember, you are not alone. On this site we are giving you the tools and guidance to help you follow your treatment plan safely and effectively, so that you get the best treatment possible for your cancer. We have answered some of the most common questions in this program, but remember, it is important that you call your healthcare provider if you have any other questions or if something is not clear to you.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are oral cancer drugs?
Response.Content:
An oral cancer drug is any medication taken by mouth to treat cancer. It can be a tablet, liquid or capsule. These cancer drugs are sometimes referred to as oral chemotherapy, but there are several types of drugs used to treat cancer that now come in oral form. Oral cancer drugs can be broken down into three main types: One of those types is cytotoxic, or what people commonly refer to as chemotherapy or chemo. The other types are targeted therapies, and hormonal agents.
For more information on each type of medication, look in the related questions area.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is cytotoxic chemotherapy?
Response.Content:
Cytotoxic chemotherapy, often just called chemo, goes through your whole body to kill cancer cells. It generally works by keeping the cancer cells from dividing and forming new cells. Most chemotherapy drugs also keep normal, healthy cells from dividing, and this is what causes some of the side effects. Cells that normally divide quickly, such as the hair follicles, reproductive tract, digestive tract, and bone marrow cells are the most affected.
Some common side effects of oral chemotherapy are: • Bone marrow suppression, which can make you more likely to get infections or increase your risk of bleeding • Anemia, or low red blood cells, which can make you tired and short of breath • Gastrointestinal problems including mouth sores, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea • Peripheral neuropathy, which is nerve pain or loss of sensation in your hands and feet • Hair loss also called alopecia • Problems with your vision • And confusion and memory problems
For more information on these and other side effects, look in the related questions area.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are targeted cancer therapies?
Response.Content:
Targeted therapy is used to keep cancer from growing and spreading. These drugs target specific parts of cancer cells to keep them from developing into tumors. They also work to shrink existing tumors.
Targeted therapies work in several different ways. Some block the action of enzymes, proteins, and other molecules involved in the growth and spread of cancer cells. Others help your immune system attack and kill cancer cells; and a third kind of targeted therapy poisons cancer cells directly, without affecting healthy cells. Because of the specific ways targeted therapies work, their side effects can be different from those caused by other chemotherapy drugs.
Some common side effects of targeted therapies are: • Diarrhea • Liver problems such as hepatitis • Skin problems such as rashes • Problems with blood clotting and wound healing • High blood pressure • Nausea and vomiting • Fatigue • Hand-foot syndrome which is redness, swelling, and pain like pins and needles on the palms of the hands or the soles of the feet. • Damage to the heart • And bone marrow suppression which can make you more likely to get an infection, cause shortness of breath or problems with stopping bleeding.
Targeted therapies also have the potential for many dangerous drug interactions. It is important to tell your healthcare providers about all medications and supplements you are taking. Make sure that you list everything; including over the counter pain relievers, cold and allergy medicines, skin creams and patches, eye drops, vitamins and holistic medications. Also, if another healthcare provider prescribes any new medications for you, make sure to check and see that there are no interactions with the cancer medications you are taking.
Information on drug interactions for specific medications can be found in the Food and Drug Administration information that comes with your prescription. You can also find a link to a drug interaction tool in the Resources Area, or you can ask your pharmacist about the specific medications you're taking.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are hormone therapies?
Response.Content:
Hormone therapies slow or stop the growth of cancers that need hormones to grow. These cancer drugs can work in two different ways. They can either prevent the body from producing the hormones that cause cancer growth, or they can stop the hormones from reaching the cancer cells. Known hormone dependent cancers include breast, prostate, endometrial, kidney and ovarian.
The side effects from hormone therapy depend on the type of drug you receive, and side effects can be different for women and men.
Common side effects include: • Hot flashes • Loss of interest in or ability to have sex • Insomnia or the inability to fall or stay asleep • Joint pain • And weakening of bones
Men taking hormone therapy drugs may also experience: • Impotence, or inability to get and keep an erection • Shrinking of the testicles • And development of opposite sex characteristics such as enlarged breast tissue

Response.BaseQuestion: Where will I get my oral cancer drugs?
Response.Content:
Your healthcare provider will prescribe the medication that is most effective for your type of cancer. You may be able to get your medications right at your doctor's office or through the hospital pharmacy. At these locations there may be staff specially trained in oral cancer medications that can help educate you and answer any questions you have about your prescriptions.
If you are not able to get your oral cancer drugs from your healthcare provider or hospital, you can get your prescription filled at a pharmacy. Unfortunately, many local and chain pharmacies won't be able to fill your prescription for oral cancer drugs, and may not know the ins and outs of billing for these medications, especially if you are on Medicare Part B.
Instead, you may use a specialty pharmacy. Prescriptions filled at specialty pharmacies may be sent directly to you through the mail. These pharmacies often work closely with Medicare and insurance plans, so they are usually familiar with billing and co-payments. And, they may also have specially trained staff to provide instructions and information by phone or mail. Your healthcare provider or insurance provider should be able to help you find a specialty pharmacy.
Before filling your prescription, it may be a good idea to check with your healthcare plan to make sure your cancer meds are covered, and to find out if your health plan requires you to use a specific pharmacy.
Make sure to order refills when you have one to two weeks of pills left so you don't run out. And, if you are going away, make sure to have enough medication to take with you.
There is more information on pharmacies and insurance in the Resource Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: Why are co-payments for oral cancer drugs so high?
Response.Content:
Cancer drugs taken by mouth can be very expensive because most health insurance plans do not pay for oral cancer drugs the same way as they pay for I-V cancer drugs.
Health care plans usually cover I-V cancer treatments as a medical benefit because they are given in a hospital or doctor's office. You usually pay only a minimal co-pay or nothing at all for that medication.
However, oral cancer drugs usually come under a health plan's pharmacy benefit, and are treated like any other prescription drug. This can mean larger co-pays.
Many states have passed laws, called parity laws, which make oral cancer drugs more affordable for patients. These laws require health plans to make out-of-pocket costs the same, regardless of how your cancer treatment is given. However, these laws do not apply to Medicare.
To find out if your state has passed this law or for more information on this issue check out the links in the Resources Area.
If you have trouble paying for your oral cancer medication there may be help. Many drug manufacturers will help you pay for their drugs. Also, talk with your healthcare team for other resources that may be able to help you pay for your oral cancer medications.
If you would like more information about help with paying for oral cancer drugs or insurance issues, look in the Resources Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: How does the doctor calculate my dose?
Response.Content:
Your doctor will match your dose to your type of cancer and the stage of your cancer. They may adjust your dose depending on your height and weight. Your dose may also be adjusted if you are older or if you have other health conditions.
Your dose is calculated just for you, so it is important to take your medications exactly as instructed. Taking more medication than prescribed can be dangerous and cause life threatening side effects. Taking less medication than prescribed is just as dangerous and could even make the medication not work as well. This is why it is very important that you tell your healthcare team about anything that interferes with your ability to take your oral cancer drugs as prescribed. You must get the right dose of medication that treats your cancer with the fewest side effects possible.

Response.BaseQuestion: What do I need to know about my medication?
Response.Content:
Getting a cancer diagnosis can send you into a whirlwind of emotions. While you are still reeling from the news, you are bombarded with tests, information and treatment options. Sometimes it's hard to remember what you've been told, but it is important to know as much about your medication as possible. It may help to write down a list of questions to ask your healthcare provider.
Here are some things you should know about your medication: • The name and spelling of your drug • The reason you are taking it • How it works • What the dose is • What time you should take it and how often • How many days or months you may need to continue taking the medication • What to do if you miss a dose or take too much • And whether to take it with or without food or water • You should know what foods, drinks or activities should be avoided while taking your medication • And whether there are there any other drugs, prescription or over-the-counter, that you should avoid • You should also find out how to properly dispose of left over medication.
You can go to the Resources Area to print out this list and take it with you to your doctor's visit. It's important that you keep in touch with your healthcare team and ask them any questions you have about your medication or treatment plan. Also, every time you start a new medication or get a refill from the pharmacy, you should double check the name on the pill bottle to make sure it is your medication; and the name and spelling of the drug, to make sure it is the correct medication.
You should always read the Food and Drug Administration insert that comes with your cancer medication. It will tell you about any possible food or drug interactions. There is also a link to drug interaction tool in Resources Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: Why must I take my oral cancer drugs exactly as prescribed?
Response.Content: Oral cancer doses are set up so a patient has a constant level of the drugs in the body to kill cancer cells. This means even a tiny increase or decrease in the dose can be harmful. If the treatment plan isn't followed, your treatment may not be as effective. It can also lead to additional and possibly severe side effects. You should never crush, split or chew oral cancer pills because it can affect how quickly medication dissolves and can impact how well the drug works. Also, more is not better when it comes to oral cancer drugs. Do not take more than the prescribed dose. It can cause dangerous side effects.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I remember to take my medications?
Response.Content:
Your drug treatment plan is designed for you and your specific type of cancer. Sometimes the instructions may seem confusing, but it is important to take your medications exactly as prescribed. Not taking them properly can cause side effects and could affect how well the drug works. Making a plan and establishing a routine often helps people keep on track. There are many tools to help you, from smartphone apps to old fashion diaries. It doesn't matter what you use, as long as you use it consistently.
If you have a smartphone or tablet, go to the app store and search for pill reminders. You will see a large list of apps. Check them out to see which one will work the best for you. Look for one that can be personalized to your lifestyle and is easy to use. Some apps have an actual picture of the drug you are taking and will automatically send you text reminders to take your meds. Electronic medication reminders are also available. These are basically pillboxes with alarms to remind you when it is time to take your meds. There are basic, affordable models as well as more advanced and expensive models.
If you don't want to deal with computers or electronics, you can use a paper calendar or pill diary. Keep the calendar in a location that you see daily and mark down when you take your pills.
For more ideas on ways to remember to take your oral cancer drugs, check out the Resources Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I deal with stress?
Response.Content:
Everything about cancer is stressful, but knowing when your stress level is too high and becoming serious is important.
Some signs to look out for are:
• You have feelings of being overwhelmed to the point of panic • You have trouble concentrating. • You feel so irritable that it is hard to be around other people, even people you care about, or if others find it hard to be around you. • You feel unable to cope with pain, tiredness, and nausea
Other signs that your stress levels are too high are: • You have trouble getting to sleep, staying asleep, or are getting less than 4 hours of sleep a night • You have trouble eating for a few weeks • You have lost interest in activities that are usually pleasurable • Or you feel a loss of control or loss of confidence
Talk to your healthcare team if you have any of these symptoms. There is a tool, much like a pain scale, that you can use to help measure your stress level. For more on this screening tool, check out the Resources Area on this page.

Response.BaseQuestion: Which foods should I avoid?
Response.Content:
Some foods can cause problems when taken with oral cancer drugs. It is important to know what foods you can and cannot eat. For instance, there is a substance in some juices that can change how some cancer drugs are absorbed by the body. This can affect how the drug works, making it stronger or weaker. Grapefruit and its juice, along with Seville oranges, pineapple, pomegranate and star fruit are some of the most common foods that patients are told to avoid. Your healthcare team can tell you what you should not eat or drink with the specific medication you are taking. You can also find this information on the Food and Drug Administration insert that comes with your medication.
For more information on food and drug interactions check out the Resources Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I get enough nutrition?
Response.Content:
When you have cancer and are taking oral cancer agents, there are a number of side effects that can make it difficult for you to get the nutrition you need to keep your energy and strength up.
Mouth sores, nausea, vomiting and diarrhea can all keep you from eating or absorbing vitamins and fuel that your body needs.
Let your healthcare team know about any side effects that are keeping you from eating. If you're too tired to cook or the smell of food cooking makes you feel sick to your stomach, ask your healthcare provider about adding a nutritional supplement such as a meal replacement shake or bar. You could also ask someone else to prepare meals ahead of time and freeze them to cut down on the amount of cooking you need to do.

Response.BaseQuestion: Can I continue to take my other medications?
Response.Content: Before you begin taking your oral cancer medication, make sure you tell your healthcare provider all the prescription and non-prescription medicines you are taking. This is very important because some medicines can change the way cancer drugs work. Make a list with the name of the drug, the dose, how often you take it, who prescribed it and why you are taking it. Take this list with you to your healthcare provider's visit. Be sure to include any herbal and dietary supplements, vitamins and minerals and over-the-counter medications like aspirin, acetaminophen, ibuprofen, allergy medications, or cough and cold medicines. Even eye drops, skin cream or patches can affect how well your cancer drugs work, and may also cause side effects or dangerous drug interactions. Your healthcare provider will tell you if you should stop taking any of your regular medications before you start your cancer treatment. Make sure you always check with your healthcare provider before taking any new medications or supplements.

Response.BaseQuestion: Can I still take herbal supplements after I start my oral cancer meds?
Response.Content:

Response.BaseQuestion: Can I work while taking oral cancer drugs?

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I get through work while taking cancer treatments?
Response.Content:
Oral cancer drugs may make working through treatment a bit easier since you won't have to leave work to go to a treatment center, but side effects can still cause challenges.

There are other things that may help you keep working through treatment, for instance:

This might help you save energy and allow you to take care of yourself more easily if you have problems. • If possible, get help at home with daily chores like housekeeping and cooking. Response.BaseQuestion: What if I can't work during my treatment?
Response.Content:
Sometimes, even with good planning and extra time off, it may be too much to keep working during cancer treatment.
Talk with your healthcare team about how your treatment and symptoms are affecting your work. This may help you decide if or when you should think about taking time off.
Plan for possible disability early. Don't put off taking leave until your work performance suffers. If you are fired for doing a poor job, you can lose your health insurance as well as your income. And, if you're fired, you cannot collect disability benefits.
If your treatment starts causing too many problems for you at work, talk to your supervisor.
Explain that you want to keep working, but you need to take some time off.
Talk to someone from your human resources department to find out if you have short-term or long-term disability insurance at your job.
If you do, get applications for both -- just in case.
In general, short-term disability pays you some portion of your income for the first few months you are unable to work.
If you must be out longer, some employers also carry long-term disability insurance, which usually starts after 6 months of disability. You must meet the insurance company's definition of disability to get this income.
Even if your company does not offer disability insurance, you may still qualify for family medical leave under the FMLA program. For more information on this program, look in the Resources Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I safely handle and store oral cancer drugs?
Response.Content: Taking oral cancer meds at home is more convenient, but these drugs are still very powerful and must be handled and stored carefully. It is important to protect others from coming into contact with your cancer medication. Oral chemotherapy, hormones, and targeted therapies used in cancer treatment should be regarded as hazardous drugs. Oral cancer drugs usually come in the form of a capsule or tablet. They may contain traces of hazardous drugs on their surfaces. The outsides of bottles or blister packs may also contain traces of the drugs. Even though it may only be a trace amount, it can be absorbed through skin, inhaled, or ingested or can transfer to surfaces if not handled properly. Pregnant caregivers should never handle oral cancer medication.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I administer oral cancer drugs at home?
Response.Content:
Remember oral cancer drugs are powerful and potentially hazardous.
Make sure you and your caregiver take these special precautions to stay safe when handling oral cancer medications: • Cancer drugs should remain in their original packaging until used or placed into daily pill boxes. • Be careful not to inhale any dust that might enter the air when you open the pill bottle or package. • Do not let the medication come in contact with household surfaces like countertops or tables, and if they do, clean the surface thoroughly afterwards to prevent others from coming in contact with traces of the drugs. • Whenever possible, you should handle your drugs yourself. • Wash your hands well before and after handling the pills. • If anyone else is giving you your medication, they should put the pill into a medication cup or onto a spoon. Then you can tip the cup or spoon to your mouth to take the pills. • Oral cancer drugs should not be crushed, split, broken or chewed. • Caregivers should wear disposable gloves when handling oral cancer drugs. Used gloves should never be re-used. They should be thrown in the regular household trash after one use. • Caregivers should wash their hands with soap and water after removing and throwing away the gloves. • Pregnant caregivers should not handle oral cancer drugs. • Also, pill containers for cancer drugs should never be reused. • Remember to keep all drugs out of the reach of children and pets.

Response.BaseQuestion: How do I store oral cancer drugs?

Keeping your medications in their original containers will limit contamination and ensure that you always have the information about the name of the medication, the dose and other instructions. This is especially important if you are on multiple medications. • Do not let your chemotherapy drugs come into contact with your other medications. They should always remain separate. • Remember to wash your hands with soap and water after handling. Caregivers should always wear disposable gloves when handling cancer medications. • Do not mix your oral cancer drugs with other meds in the pill box. • Keep your meds in a cool, dry place away from heat, sunlight, or moisture. Bathrooms can be especially humid, so do not store your pills there. • Store oral chemotherapy drugs away from food and drinks, and keep the pills out of reach of children and pets.

Response.BaseQuestion: What precautions do I or my caregivers need to take when handling soiled laundry?
Response.Content:
Caregivers in the home should wear disposable gloves when handling any body fluids from people taking oral cancer pills.
It takes about 48 hours for the body to break down or get rid of most cancer drugs. During that time a small amount of the drug comes out in urine, stool, vomit and blood. Many oral chemotherapy agents are taken over months and sometimes even years without a break in treatment. In these cases there will be a small amount of the drug in urine, stool, vomit, and blood at all time. This means that special precautions must be followed continuously.
Items soiled with body fluids should be kept in plastic bags until washed and should be washed separately from other laundry.
Pregnant caregivers should be very careful to not come into contact with oral cancer medications or bodily fluids.
Low-pressure toilets should be double-flushed after use by people taking oral cancer drugs, and always close the toilet lid before flushing. Be sure to wipe down any splashing that may have occurred with a disinfectant cleaner.
Take special care to keep pets or small children from playing in or drinking from the toilet. If possible, designate one bathroom in the home for your own personal use.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can we handle body waste?
Response.Content:
Small amounts of chemotherapy medication are released from the body through urine, stool, vomit and blood for up to 48 hours after you stop taking your cancer medication. Many oral chemotherapy agents are taken over months and sometimes even years without a break in treatment. In these cases there will be a small amount of drug in urine, stool, vomit and blood at all times. This means that special precautions must be followed continuously.
While taking oral cancer drugs, use these precautions to protect others from exposure to your body fluids:
• After using the toilet, close the lid and flush twice. • Men should try to avoid splashing when urinating. Sitting down when urinating is a good way to avoid accidental splashing. • After using the toilet, wash hands well with soap and water. If any fluids splashed on your skin, clean the area with soap and water. • If any fluids splash on any surface make sure to clean it well with a disinfectant cleaner.
Caregivers or others living with you also need to take precautions to avoid coming into contact with your body fluids.
Caregivers should:
• Wear gloves when cleaning the toilet or cleaning up any urine, stool, vomit or blood, or when changing diapers or incontinence pads. They should dispose of gloves in the trash, then wash their hands thoroughly with soap and water.
• If emptying a bedpan or urinal, they should wear gloves and dump contents into the toilet close to the water to limit splashing. While wearing the gloves, they should wash the container with soap and water after each use.
• Diapers should be double-bagged and can then be disposed of in the regular trash.
If you have an ostomy, it is best to use disposable pouches if possible, rather than rinsing and reusing them. If disposable pouches are not possible, the collection bag should be washed once a day with soap and water.

Response.BaseQuestion: What about sex and intimate contact?
Response.Content: It is safe to touch, and hug your loved ones while you are taking cancer drugs. You should keep a list of all the prescription and non-prescription medicines you are taking, including over-the-counter medications, skin patches, creams, eye drops, nasal sprays, vitamins and herbal supplements. Response.BaseQuestion: How do I manage side effects?
Response.Content:
Taking oral cancer drugs at home is much more convenient, and some people think they will have fewer and less severe side effects.
Unfortunately, that is not always the case. Most people will have at least some side effects.
The severity of side effects varies from drug to drug and person to person.
Side effects from cancer meds affect how you feel physically and mentally. They are one of the main reasons people fail to follow their treatment plan.
If you experience side effects after taking your cancer drugs, do not stop taking your medication. Talk to your healthcare team as soon as you begin experiencing any side effects because many can be successfully managed.
If not treated early some side effects can become serious, even life threatening. It's very important to know the side effects that are specific to your oral cancer drugs and when to report them. There are symptoms that need immediate attention and need to be reported to your healthcare provider right away. Call your healthcare team immediately if you have any of the following:
• A temperature of 100.4 degrees Fahrenheit • Chest pain • Trouble breathing • Stomach swelling, tenderness, or pain • Dark urine • Bloody or dark stool • Nausea or vomiting despite taking anti-nausea medications • Moderate to severe pain or cramps • Or severe diarrhea

Response.BaseQuestion: Will my hair fall out?
Response.Content:
One of the most distressing side effects from cancer drugs is hair loss, also called alopecia. The scalp is not the only area affected. Hair found anywhere on the body, including eyebrows, eyelashes, facial hair, underarm hair and pubic hair can be affected.
Not all patients lose their hair during cancer treatment. You may lose all your hair or just some; it all depends on the kind of drug and dosage you are taking. And some oral cancer drugs can also cause changes in the texture, color, and growth pattern of your hair.
Hair loss doesn't happen overnight. It is usually a gradual process happening over one to three weeks after the first treatment cycle. For others it may happen over several treatment cycles.
Hair loss can be a source of anxiety or social isolation as it is a visual reminder of your diagnosis and treatment. It can be helpful to develop a plan with your health care provider for what you can do in terms of wigs, scarves or hats before actually losing your hair. If your hair does fall out, be sure to protect your scalp from the sun and cold.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is the treatment for diarrhea?
Response.Content:
Medication and dietary changes may help you minimize or avoid the effects of diarrhea caused by cancer drugs.
The most effective treatment for diarrhea with oral cancer drugs is medication. Your healthcare provider may recommend that you take loperamide, commonly known as Imodium, which is available over the counter, or they may prescribe another medication, such as Octreotide. Make sure you talk to your healthcare provider before you take any over-the-counter or prescription medications.
You can also make some dietary changes that may help.
• Eat small, frequent meals with foods containing soluble fiber like bananas, rice, well-cooked eggs, mashed potatoes, applesauce, and canned fruits and vegetables.
• Avoid foods that are high in fiber or fat, fried foods, dairy, alcohol, caffeine and insoluble fiber including raw fruit and vegetables, nuts, popcorn, skins, and seeds.
If you have diarrhea, you need to make sure you drink enough fluid so you do not become dehydrated. Drink 8-10 glasses of clear fluids a day. Clear fluids include water, non-caffeinated sports drinks, broth, weak and decaffeinated teas, clear juices and gelatin.
For more on actions you can take to minimize this side effect check out our Resources Area.

It is important to call your healthcare team if medication and dietary changes aren't helping your diarrhea or you have any of the following symptoms:
• A sharp increase in the number of stools per day or an increase in ostomy output • If you are unable to control your bowels • If the diarrhea interferes with your daily activities • If you have a fever 100.4 degrees Fahrenheit or higher
You should also contact your healthcare provider if you have • Moderate to severe abdominal cramping, pain, straining, or bloating • Dizziness • Dark urine • Black or bloody stool • Or a sudden rapid or irregular heartbeat

Response.BaseQuestion: What is nausea and vomiting?
Response.Content:
Nausea is the feeling of needing or wanting to vomit, and vomiting is the act of throwing up.
Nausea and vomiting is described in three ways.
Acute-onset nausea occurs within a few minutes to several hours after taking cancer meds and goes away within the first 24 hours.
Delayed-onset nausea and vomiting occurs more than 24 hours after taking cancer meds.
And anticipatory nausea and vomiting is a side effect that can occur before you receive your next chemotherapy treatment.
Nausea can become serious if it prevents you from taking or keeping down your medication, food and liquids. Uncontrolled vomiting can lead to:
• Dehydration • Poor nutrition • Fatigue
Nausea and vomiting can affect how well your treatment works and can make it necessary for the healthcare providers to reduce your doses or even delay your treatment. It can even be life threatening if it is not managed.

Response.BaseQuestion: What can be done to help ease nausea and vomiting side effect?
Response.Content:
The most effective way to prevent vomiting is to take anti-nausea medications prescribed by your healthcare provider. In most cases, if the oral cancer drugs you are taking are known to cause nausea and vomiting, your healthcare provider will prescribe medications for you to prevent these symptoms. If you are not given medication, and then you have nausea and vomiting or have vomiting even if taking these medications, call your healthcare team right away. Do not wait. It can be difficult to eliminate the sensation of nausea, however current medications used for this are extremely effective to prevent vomiting.
There are also some dietary changes you can try that may also help.
• Eat small, frequent meals. • Avoid spicy, fatty, or highly salted foods. • Drink fluids throughout the day like water and juices. If you are vomiting it is important to replace lost fluids in order to avoid becoming dehydrated.
Some patients also find that progressive muscle relaxation helps with nausea and vomiting.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is fatigue?
Response.Content:
Fatigue is one of the most common symptoms experienced by people with cancer.
Most patients describe this as much more than just feeling tired. It is a feeling of complete physical and mental exhaustion where even the smallest effort seems impossible.
Usually, it is not the result of activity or exertion, and it is not relieved by rest or sleep.
Fatigue can be caused by many things, so it is important to tell your healthcare team if you notice a change in your energy level.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is the treatment for fatigue?
Response.Content:
Moving around may seem like the last thing you want to do when you are tired, but physical activity has been found to be one of the most helpful ways to reduce fatigue.
The right level of activity depends on your lifestyle and health, so always talk to your healthcare team about what activities you can do safely.
Ask your healthcare team for an "activity prescription" -- this will give you a recommended type, duration and frequency of physical activity. In general, recommendations for people during treatment for cancer is the same as that for the general population: about 30 minutes a day, at least 3 days per week, as long as you do not have other conditions that limit your ability to exercise.
There are some things to remember when you start becoming more physical active:
• Start slowly. This may mean just walking around the dining room table once. Try to go a little further each time. This allows your body time to adjust. • Try to do some kind of physical activity every day or at least every other day. • The right kind of activity should never make you feel sore, stiff, or exhausted.
If you experience any of these feelings you may be overdoing it and it may be time to call your healthcare team.
Also, tell your healthcare team if you experience any of the following:
• Fatigue that limits your ability to care for yourself • Increased shortness of breath with little activity • Dizziness • Uncontrolled pain • Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or loss of appetite • Uncontrollable anxiety or nervousness • Ongoing depression
For more ideas on combating fatigue, click on the Resources Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is anxiety?
Response.Content:
A cancer diagnosis can be scary, and it can cause anxiety in many patients. Anxiety is a feeling of worry, nervousness or unease. It can cause panic attacks and may also have an effect on your ability to think clearly and on your job performance, relationships, and other daily activities.
It's normal to have some anxiety, but there are things you can do to reduce these feelings so that they don't affect your treatment plan.

Some symptoms of anxiety are:
• Excessive worry about events or activities • Muscle tension • Sleep changes -- either being unable to sleep or sleeping more than usual • Physical symptoms such as rapid heartbeat, sweating, palpitations, trembling, shortness of breath, chest tightness, nausea, diarrhea, flushing, dizziness, or high blood pressure • Exhaustion • Difficulty concentrating • And irritability or restlessness

Response.BaseQuestion: What is the treatment for constipation?
Response.Content:
There are some things you can do to prevent or relieve constipation.
You can: • Eat foods high in fiber like fruits, cereals, and vegetables. Prune, pear and apple juices may help. You may also consider meeting with a nutritionist to discuss your diet. • Drink two to three liters of non-alcoholic fluids each day, unless your healthcare provider tells you otherwise. • Stay physically active.
Pain medication often cause constipation. If you are taking pain medication, you may want to take a stool softener or laxative to prevent constipation. Remember to always talk to your healthcare provider before taking any over-the-counter or prescription medicines. There are also medications your healthcare provider can recommend for constipation, if these methods don't help.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is depression?
Response.Content:
A cancer diagnosis may cause anyone to feel sad or down, but when that sadness persists and affects your usual activities you may be depressed. Depression can be a side effect of many cancer drugs. It could be a sign that your cancer medication or treatment needs to be adjusted.
Do not wait to contact your healthcare team if you think you may be depressed. If un-treated, depression only gets worse. The sooner you let your healthcare team know how you are feeling, the sooner you can find relief. Your healthcare provider may prescribe anti-depressants. Remember it can take up to two weeks for antidepressant medication to begin working. You may also be referred to a counselor to help you find ways to cope with your situation. Getting professional help for depression is just as important as taking your medications. Relaxation therapy can also be helpful.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is peripheral neuropathy?
Response.Content:
Some cancer drugs can cause a side effect called peripheral neuropathy. It is a nerve problem that causes pain, burning, numbness, and tingling in the hands or feet.
Other Symptoms of peripheral neuropathy are: • Numbness around the mouth • Loss of sensation to touch.
Peripheral neuropathy can lead to: • Difficulty walking and balancing • Injuries caused by loss of sensation and balance • Constipation • Hearing loss or ringing in your ears.
Peripheral neuropathy can be temporary or it can become chronic and long-term.
If you are experiencing any of these symptoms talk to your healthcare team. A combination of medication and therapies are often helpful relieving symptoms.
For more information peripheral neuropathy click on the Resources Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is the treatment for peripheral neuropathy?
Response.Content:
The most effective treatment to prevent and treat peripheral neuropathy is medication that can be prescribed by your healthcare provider.
There are a variety of other treatments you can try to help ease the pain from nerve damage. Working with physical therapy to improve balance has been shown to be helpful. Acupuncture, physical therapy and gentle massage have shown mixed results when treating the symptoms of nerve damage. But some people find them helpful. You should not take nutritional supplements on your own to try to manage this problem, as some supplements have been shown to make things worse.

The damage to your nerves may keep you from feeling the discomfort of blisters, cuts, or burns that if left untreated can become infected. If your balance is affected, you should take precautions to avoid falls and other accidents around the house.

Response.BaseQuestion: Will I experience a loss of sexual desire?
Response.Content:
Cancer treatments can cause sexual changes for some patients. This is not unusual, and you are not alone.
The most common issue is overall loss of desire. Just dealing with side effects from your cancer treatment may take so much energy that sex is not high on your priority list.
For women, vaginal dryness and pain are often reported. For men, erectile problems are common. Most men and women are still able to have an orgasm, but it is common to need more time or stimulation to reach orgasm. If you are not receiving treatment for a hormone sensitive tumor, you may be a candidate for hormone replacement treatment.
One of the most important things you can do is to share your concerns with your partner and talk to your healthcare team.

Response.BaseQuestion: Is it normal to be more forgetful and confused?
Response.Content:
Some people experience memory problems or a mental cloudiness, which is sometimes called "chemo brain".
Patients often describe trouble concentrating, forgetfulness, trouble multi-tasking, taking longer to finish things and trouble remembering common words. These problems have been a known side effect of radiation treatment, but only recently have been linked to chemotherapy and other cancer treatments. For most people these changes last only a short time, but for others it can go on for years and can affect your everyday life. So tell your healthcare team about any changes in your thinking or behavior that begins to affect your lifestyle.
There are also some physical conditions than can cause confusion. They include: • Dehydration • Anemia • Heart problems • A severe infection in your blood or central nervous system • Thyroid disorders • Depression • Lack of Sleep • And alcohol use or abuse.
Make sure you and your healthcare team rule out any of these conditions.

Response.Content: Skin reactions are an extremely common side effect of cancer treatment. Reactions range from mild to severe, and they can negatively affect your quality of life. Some skin reactions can even be serious and potentially life threatening. Treatments are available, so make sure your healthcare provider knows about any skin reactions you experience.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a rash?
Response.Content:
The most common type of skin reaction is a rash. It is often bright red in color and the skin may feel hot, burning, or itchy. The rash may begin with a small, raised pimple or small pus-filled blister or may be a flat reddened area on the skin. It typically appears on the face, scalp, and upper chest and back and can look like acne. The rash may extend over your entire body except for the palms of the hands and soles of the feet. Most rashes start early in treatment, usually during the first two weeks, and can develop into a secondary infection of lesions.
You may also have other symptoms including: • Peeling of the skin • Wet or dry open so • Fever • Swollen lymph nodes • And loss of appetite.
There are many other kinds of skin reactions caused by cancer medications.
For more on those conditions and ways to manage a rash check our Resources Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: How do I treat a rash?
Response.Content:
There are medications that may help relieve the symptoms of a rash, so make sure your healthcare provider is aware of any skin issues. In addition to the medications, you can play an important role in managing this symptom by caring for your skin throughout treatment.
Things you can do are: • Moisturize your skin with products that are hypoallergenic and free of perfume or alcohol. • Use gentle soaps and shampoos when washing. Avoid lotions or gels containing alcohol. • Pat skin dry with a soft, clean towel to reduce the risk of infection. • Shave with caution. • Wear smooth, non-binding clothing made of natural fibers. • Avoid sun exposure. When outdoors wear a hat and protective clothing, and use sunscreen that provides protection against both UVA and UVB rays. • Use makeup that does not clog skin pores. • Monitor for signs of infection and report symptoms to the healthcare team.
Your healthcare provider may prescribe medications to prevent and treat the rash and relieve any itching. Do not treat a chemo-related rash with anti-acne medications. Chemo-related rash is very different from acne and the treatment is as well.
It is not unusual for your healthcare provider to change the dosage of your oral cancer drug as needed to balance your treatment effectiveness while reducing skin side effects. Do not change your dosage unless instructed by your healthcare provider.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are some other skin problems that can come from oral cancer drugs?
Response.Content:
People taking targeted therapy drugs may have other skin reactions. These kinds of drugs can cause severe dry skin, a severe acne-like rash, or fissures, which are cuts or cracks in the skin.
Some measures you can take to prevent these skin problems are: • Take baths or showers with lukewarm water. • Use small amounts of soap or use oils rather than soap. • And apply a thick moisturizer at least daily. • Avoid skin contact with solvents or disinfectants, and wear gloves when doing things like housecleaning or dishes.
Fissures are best treated with a medical-grade liquid skin adhesive for immediate closure. Your healthcare provider should be able to tell you what product to use.

Response.BaseQuestion: Will my skin darken?
Response.Content:
The darkening of the skin is called hyperpigmentation and it is a common skin reaction, particularly in dark-skinned people.
This can occur as an overall darkening of the skin, or it can be localized, showing up in areas exposed to light as a golden brown or slate grey color change.
Some drugs may also cause darkening of the skin over the finger joints and under the nails, as well as the tongue and gums.
Most hyperpigmentation occurs within two to three weeks after starting treatment and goes away 10 to 12 weeks after stopping treatment. Occasionally the hyperpigmentation may be permanent.

Response.Content:
Call your healthcare team as soon as symptoms of hand foot syndrome appear as it is important to treat this side effect.
There are some things you can do to manage hand foot syndrome: • Avoid hot water, bathe in lukewarm water to reduce symptoms. • Avoid high-impact exercise or activities. • Avoid actions that will put pressure on the palms, like using garden tools or kitchen knives. • Keep your toenails short and wear shoes that do not push on nails -- tight shoes don't necessarily cause this problem, but can make hand-foot syndrome worse and cause discomfort.
If symptoms do not improve, call your healthcare team. They may recommend cleaning with antiseptic solutions, such as a weak vinegar or very weak bleach solution. Topical and other medications may be needed.

Response.BaseQuestion: Will I experience sleep problems?
Response.Content:
Sleep problems are reported by up to 90 percent of patients with cancer.
Often times, cancer drugs cause people to feel tired and sleepy throughout the day. They end up napping or sleeping during the day and that leads to difficulty sleeping at night.
Sometimes sleep problems are caused by medications prescribed to combat the side effects of chemotherapy.
Stress and tension about your diagnosis and treatment can also cause sleep problems. Other side effect such as hot flashes, peripheral neuropathy and fatigue can contribute to sleep disturbance.
Depending on the reasons you are having trouble sleeping, your health care provider may prescribe medication to help you sleep better.
And, there are some things you can do to help improve your sleep: • When you rise each day try to get at least 20 min of exposure to bright, natural light. • Make sure you are taking your medications at the right time of day. • Try not to take naps during the day. • Cut down on caffeine and especially avoid drinking caffeine in the evening. • Also, do not eat or exercise within 2 hours of bedtime. • Keep a consistent sleep schedule. Go to bed and wake up at the same time each day. • Start a routine before bedtime, using a relaxation technique you prefer that does not include using a computer screen or watching TV. • Use your bed only for sleeping, not for watching TV or reading. • Make your room dark, cool and quiet. • If you are unable to get to sleep, don't stay in the bed. Do something to help you relax.
If you are still having problems sleeping, try keeping a sleep diary to show to your healthcare provider.
For more on keeping a sleep diary check out the Resources Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: Will there be changes to the way things taste?
Response.Content: About 50% of people experience taste changes during treatment. The exact reason for taste changes is not clear, but it is might be a result of the damage to the cells in the oral cavity, which are especially sensitive to cancer drugs. Many people say they can no longer tolerate spicy foods and describe most food as tasting bland, bitter, or like chemicals. These changes may occur during your drug therapy and last for hours, days, weeks, or even months after treatment stops. There are no medications to help with taste changes, but some studies have suggested deficiencies in vitamins and minerals can lead to taste changes. Talk to your healthcare provider before adding any vitamins or supplements to your diet, as some may cause dangerous interactions or cause your cancer medications to be less effective. Check out the Resources Area for ways to manage these taste changes. Also, make sure to call your healthcare provider if your taste changes have caused you to stop eating and you have lost any weight.

Response.BaseQuestion: Will I lose my appetite?
Response.Content:
Many people taking cancer medications report a loss of appetite or no desire to eat. This can be caused by pain, depression, nausea and vomiting or advanced disease.
Some things that may help with your lack of appetite are: • Eat small meals or snacks, every two to three hours, instead of three large meals a day • Eat foods that are rich in nutrients and high in protein or calories. • Avoid low-calorie foods • Drink nutrient-dense fluids such as milk, milk shakes, juice and punch -type drink • Avoid heavy meals, greasy or fried foods, and foods that cause gas. • Prepare food that is colorful and appealing to the eye.
Talk to your healthcare provider about your appetite issues. There are medications that may be prescribed to combat lack of appetite. Your healthcare provider may also be able to give you a referral to a registered dietician to help you plan and implement oral nutritional interventions. Dietary supplements can also be helpful but make sure you check with your healthcare provider before taking any supplements.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is bone marrow suppression?
Response.Content:
Bone marrow is the spongy tissue in the center of the bones. It is where red and white blood cells and platelets are made. Some cancer drugs can destroy bone marrow, causing your body to produce fewer blood cells. A drop in the levels of any of these cells can lead to side effects.
Bone marrow suppression also called immune suppression, or blood cell suppression, is one of the most common reasons cancer treatment is delayed or modified. It can cause several significant dangers for cancer patients. One of the biggest dangers is infection.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a low white blood cell count?
Response.Content: White blood cells fight infection. A low white blood cell count significantly increases your risk of infection. If you have a low white blood cell count you may hear or see terms like neutropenia, leukopenia or granulocytopenia. These are the names of different types of white blood cells in your body that may be affected by your oral cancer drugs. There is nothing you can do to raise your white blood cell count on your own, but there are things you can do to reduce your risk of infection. They include: • Wash your hands often during the day, especially before you eat and use the bathroom. • Stay away from crowds. • Avoid contact with anyone who is sick. • Do not have dental work done while your white blood cell count is low. • Be careful not to cut or nick yourself. • Wear gloves when working in the garden. • Avoid emptying or handling pet waste. • Wash all fresh fruits and vegetables thoroughly. • Avoid eating uncooked or undercooked meat. • Also, if your healthcare provider recommends it and you feel comfortable, you may choose to wear a face mask when out in public.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are symptoms of infection in patients with low white cell count?
Response.Content:
Even if you are very careful your body may still not be able to fight infections. Some symptoms of infection are • Temperature over 100.4 degrees • Chills • Sweating • Painful urination • A bad cough or sore throat • Diarrhea
It is important to be alert to any change in how you feel and report any sign of infection to your healthcare team immediately.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is low red blood cell count or anemia?
Response.Content: Bone marrow suppression can cause anemia, which is a low red blood cell count. Red blood cells carry oxygen and nutrients throughout the body, so a low red blood cell count can make you feel tired and weak. To see if you have a low red blood count, your healthcare provider may order a blood test called complete blood count or CBC.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are symptoms of low red blood cell count?
Response.Content:
Symptoms of a low red blood cell count or anemia often start slowly, so you may not even notice them at first. However, as your red blood cell count gets lower, the symptoms will become more severe.
When you have a low red blood cell count you may become anemic and have these symptoms:
• Fatigue • Weakness • Shortness of breath • a racing heartbeat • Dizziness or lightheaded • Headaches • Chest Pain • Pale skin
You should contact your healthcare team if you notice any of these symptoms. Get immediate help if you have chest pain.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is the treatment for low red blood count?
Response.Content:
Depending your situation your healthcare provider may prescribe medication, an iron supplement, multivitamin, a high protein diet, or even a blood transfusion. There are some things you can do to help manage a low red blood cell count.
• Rest between activities. • Plan ahead and save energy for the most important activities. • Avoid or stop activities that make you short of breath or make your heart beat faster.
However, once you determine that your blood counts are at a safe level, it is important to gradually become more active. Learn more about increasing activity in the Resources Area.
• You should also maintain a well-balanced diet including iron-rich foods. • If supplements such as iron, B12, or folate are prescribed make sure you take them. • Drink plenty of non-caffeinated and non-alcoholic fluids. • Use an electric razor to shave rather than a straight razor.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a low platelet count?
Response.Content: Another danger caused by bone marrow suppression is a low platelet count. Platelets are colorless blood cells that help blood clot. They line the inside of the blood vessel. When you have a low platelet count this layer thins and tiny drops of blood can leak through the spaces made when the layers thin. This causes red dots on the skin called petechiae (pa-TEE-kee-eye). A low blood platelet count puts you at an increased risk of bruising and bleeding.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is heart failure and congestive heart failure?
Response.Content: Another heart problem sometimes associated with oral cancer therapies is heart failure. This doesn't mean the heart has stopped working, it means the heart is not pumping blood through the body as well as it should. This can cause fluid to back up into the lungs, which is called congestive heart failure.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are symptoms of heart failure?
Response.Content:
Symptoms of congestive heart failure are:
• Overall tiredness or weakness • Shortness of breath, either at rest or while performing any type of activity • Swollen legs, especially in your feet and ankles • Feeling bloated • Chest pain which may range from excruciating to a mild discomfort • High blood pressure or low blood pressure • Irregular pulse • A slow or fast heart rate while resting • Decreased urine output • Weight gain
If you experience any of these symptoms make your healthcare provider knows. They may want to do further testing or prescribe medication.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is hypertension?
Response.Content:
Hypertension or high blood pressure is another heart problem associated with oral cancer therapies. Most people don't notice any symptoms of high blood pressure. This is why high blood pressure is known as "the silent killer."
Symptoms of hypertension are:
• Elevated blood pressure greater than 139/90 • Slow heart rate usually slower than 60 beats per minute • Rapid heart rate • Headache • Chest pain • Decreased urine output • Any unusual swelling in feet and legs • Weight gain of greater than 3 to 5 pounds in 1 week • Chronic dry cough • Blurred vision or decreased clarity
If you have any of these symptoms you should consult your healthcare provider.

Response.BaseQuestion: When should I call the healthcare provider about hypertension?
Response.Content:
If you suddenly experience nausea, dizziness, loss of vision, severe headaches, or confusion, seek medical help immediately. If you have hypertension, know the signs of stroke and get immediate medical help if any of these occur.
If you are on medication for high blood pressure, take your medication as ordered. Unless you check your own blood pressure regularly, you will not know if your pressure is high, and you should not stop taking your medication because you "feel OK."
There are things you can do to reduce your risk of developing high blood pressure: • Quit smoking • Exercise at least 20 to 30 minutes a day • Try to reduce the amount of stress in your life • Avoid alcohol use and limit caffeine intake • Eat a diet that is low in saturated fat and cholesterol, low in sodium • And lose weight if you are overweight

Response.BaseQuestion: What is dry mouth?
Response.Content:
Dry mouth can be caused by a number of things, including medication, dehydration, or a fungal infection of the mouth. There are medications your healthcare provider can prescribe to treat dry mouth, but there are also some things you can try on your own that can to help alleviate this problem.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is dehydration?
Response.Content:
Dehydration is an excessive loss of body fluids and occurs when the output of fluid exceeds fluid intake.
Dehydration can be caused by: • Vomiting or diarrhea • Infections • High fever • Bleeding • Or even something as simple as not drinking enough fluids
Dehydration is a dangerous symptom. It can be life threatening if the signs are not recognized and treated.
Symptoms of dehydration include: • Confusion and disorientation • Excessively dry mouth, skin and mucous membranes • Skin that appears loose and crinkled and will stand up like a tent when lightly pinched and pulled up • And little or no urine output
If you have any of these symptoms inform your healthcare provider as you may need to get intravenous fluids.

Response.BaseQuestion: Do oral cancer drug cause pain?
Response.Content: Some people getting cancer treatment will have pain. The pain may come from the cancer itself or it can be a side effect of some oral cancer drugs. Pain can affect how clearly you can think and your ability to accomplish daily activities. Because it often gets worse at night, it can also interfere with sleep which can also affect how well you can concentrate the next day. Assess pain often and talk to your healthcare team about your pain, especially if it interferes with your sleep. To help your healthcare provider diagnose and manage your pain you can keep a pain diary. For more information on using a pain diary check out the Resources Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I lessen or manage the pain with medication?
Response.Content: If you have pain from your cancer and are on pain medications that need to be taken at specific times, it is important to stick to your pain medication schedule. Side effects from increasing pain medication can also make it difficult for you to manage your cancer treatment plan. Keeping pain in check by sticking to a medication schedule is the best way to manage pain and prevent the need for more medication.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is venous thromboembolism?
Response.Content: Blood clots that form in a vein are called venous thromboembolism or VTE. VTE is a frequent and serious complication in patients with cancer. The lower extremities are the most common sites for a blood clot to form. If the blood clot dislodges and gets into the blood stream it can travel to the heart or lungs causing a life threatening condition and even death. Many factors can influence the risk for developing VTE, including the type and site of cancer. The highest rate of VTE happens within the first year of a cancer diagnosis.

Response.BaseQuestion: How do I prevent blood clots?
Response.Content: To prevent blood clots keep moving. Try to walk at least 30 minutes, three times a week. Wearing compression stockings, especially if you're not able to be mobile, can also help prevent blood clots. This can be especially helpful if you'll be sitting for several hours at a time and cannot get up and walk, for instance if you're flying or riding somewhere. Avoid dehydration. Make sure you drink eight glass of fluid a day. Water is best, but sugar free and non-caffeinated drinks are an alternative. If your healthcare team thinks that you're at high risk for developing blood clots or you have already had a blood clot you may be prescribed blood thinners.

If you have shortness of breath or chest pain with or without these symptoms you need to go to the emergency room immediately.

Response.BaseQuestion: What kind of eye problems can be caused by cancer drugs?
Response.Content:
Depending on what type of oral cancer drug you are taking, you could experience some problems with your eyes or your vision.
One side effect is a condition where the eyelashes become elongated and may irritate the eye.
You should not cut the eyelashes. If the irritation continues, an ophthalmologist may need to evaluate for possible removal of the lashes.
Another eye problem caused by cancer treatment is often called dry eyes. This can cause a decrease in vision, eye pain, or the feeling of having something in your eye. For mild symptoms, artificial tears may be all that is needed. In severe cases, an ophthalmologist should be consulted for treatment.
People who are taking tamoxifen may be at greater risk for developing cataracts. Cataracts are a clouding of the normally clear lens of your eye. Cataracts can cause blurry vision, or make it seem as though you're looking through a frosty window. These vision changes are permanent unless the cataracts are removed during surgery.
You should have your vision checked before you begin treatment with tamoxifen and have it checked regularly throughout your treatment.
Let your healthcare team know if you are having any of these changes to your vision: • Cloudy or blurry vision. • Trouble seeing in the dark, or at night. • Colors appearing to be faded, or dull. • Or double vision
You may have to change your eyeglass prescription frequently during treatment as changes to your vision occur.
You should call the healthcare provider immediately if: • You have any sudden severe eye pain • You have a sudden loss of vision, or if you see halos • If your eyes become sensitive to light. • Or if your eye problems worsen or do not improve within 3 days of treatment.
Reporting symptoms to your healthcare provider early is essential, and they may need to send you to a specialist for treatment. For more information on other eye problems caused by oral cancer therapy check out the Resources Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: How do I keep a record of my symptoms and side effects?

Response.BaseQuestion: What is mucositis?
Response.Content:
Mucositis is the inflammation of any part of the digestive tract. It can cause painful sores and ulcers in the mouth, throat and lips and can interfere with your ability to eat, swallow, talk, and chew. It also puts you at risk for infection.
Mucositis is one of the most common side effects from cancer treatment and one of the most common reasons for treatment delay and dose reduction.
There is prescription medication that can treat mouth sores, so make sure your healthcare team is aware of the problem.
• To avoid mucositis, assess your mouth on a daily basis, looking for pain, redness, and ulcer formation. • Maintain good oral hygiene -- brush your teeth at least twice a day with a soft toothbrush for 90 seconds or more and floss regularly.
During treatment, you should use mouth rinses after meals and before bed to keep your mouth clean. Rinse the mouth four times daily using a saltwater or a baking soda and water mixture. Do not use mouthwashes that contain alcohol. They can cause the membranes in your mouth to dry out.
If you have mouth sores increase mouth rinse regimen to every two hours while awake. Denture wearers should remove their dentures when cleaning their mouth.
Some other things you can do to prevent mucositis are: • Avoid spicy or acidic foods, tobacco, and alcohol. • Suck on hard candy to increase saliva and keep your mouth moist. • Avoid sharp, crunchy foods to reduce the possibility of irritation and injury to your mouth. • Keep hydrated. • And avoid licking your lips as this leads to further dryness, and use a water-based moisturizer to keep lips moist.
Call your healthcare provider if you have any of the following symptoms: • Temperature above 100.4 degrees Fahrenheit • Sores and pain that interfere with eating, drinking or sleeping • Or a heavily coated tongue
For more details look in the Resources Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: Simply because they're pills does not mean you won't experience side effects to the same degree as you would with some of the other agents.
Response.Content: Sometimes there can be a misconception that oral chemotherapy drugs may not be as serious or cause the amount of side effects as that some of the more commonly known intravenous chemotherapy drugs can cause but that is simply not the case. And we are seeing more and more oral chemotherapeutic agents being used in the management of cancer today, so it is very important to know that you can see just the same level of seriousness of the side effects of oral agents as you can see with the IV agents. The same level of nausea and vomiting and simply because they're pills does not mean you won't experience side effects to the same degree as you would with some of the other agents.

Response.BaseQuestion: The biggest message I would give is to not think that you have to just deal with that along with all the other things that you're going through.
Response.Content: So psychosocial issues such as depression and anxiety very frequently go alongside with a traumatic experience like a cancer diagnosis and something as overwhelming as starting treatment for cancer. †We can very commonly see patients experience depression or a new onset anxiety that goes along with this. And I would say the biggest message is that it's not something that you just have to deal with because you're going through this diagnosis in this major life-changing event. It's something that healthcare providers are very used to managing hand-in-hand and we can often expect some level of depression and anxiety that goes along with a cancer diagnosis and starting treatment as well as a variety of other psycho social complications. So the biggest message I would give is to not think that you have to just deal with that along with all the other things that you're going through, with the cancer diagnosis and starting new treatment and to talk about that with your healthcare provider as well. There's pharmacologic agents we can use and there's many non-pharmacologic coping strategies that a lot of times cancer patients feel comforted by while undergoing therapy.

Response.BaseQuestion: Let them know what you're experiencing, how you're tolerating the drug, so that we can intervene quickly.
Response.Content: It's absolutely crucial to be in contact with your healthcare providers every step of the way. I always tell patients that everybody will experience side effects in their own unique individual way and although we may be able to anticipate some side effects everybody can experience them differently. So very important to be in contact with your healthcare provider if you notice any differences, any changes, something that may not seem like a big deal to you or your family caring for you could be a major side effect or a reason to possibly hold the drug. And you know we're learning more and more about some of these newer drugs and it's very important to be in contact with your healthcare care provider, let them know what you're experiencing, how you're tolerating the drug, so that we can intervene quickly, get you some supportive care to manage the side effects, and alter doses if we need to.

Response.BaseQuestion: Sometimes it can be uncomfortable to talk about the degree to which are experiencing diarrhea, but cannot stress enough that they really do need to know.
Response.Content: So again, stressing the importance of letting your provider know if you're experiencing it. Sometimes it can be uncomfortable to talk about the degree to which are experiencing diarrhea, but cannot stress enough that they really do need to know. And oftentimes medications can help, but there are dietary changes that can be made. We'll frequently recommend what we call the BRAT diet. B bananas, R rice, A, applesauce, T, toast and kind of slowly introducing those agents back into your diet can sometimes be helpful in controlling the amount of diarrhea you're experiencing. Introducing small bits of liquids. Again, you should be able to hold some of these agents in as far as nausea, vomiting, diarrhea. So wanting to make sure that you keep in contact with your provider if you can't, but there are these dietary modifications you can, that should help, and if they don't seeking attention.

Response.BaseQuestion: There are pharmacologic agents that can help.
Response.Content: So there are pharmacologic agents that can help. Always making sure that you have a prescription for these antiemetics on hand. As far as non-pharmacologic options, small frequent meals, usually bland meals, tepid in temperature. Anything too warm, too cold, might aggravate that nausea. Anything with lots of flavor, unfortunately, may aggravate the nausea so we'll recommend small frequent meals. Sometimes we'll hear that actually using flatware, the metal can actually aggravate nausea and sometimes using plastic utensils can help things like that. As far as fluids, again, room temperature, little bits at a time, these things can help. But of course being aware of if you're not able to keep anything down and seeking attention.

Response.BaseQuestion: It's important to know what's normal for you.
Response.Content: So important to know what's normal for you and if you notice that the amount of with which you're having diarrhea is increasing by you know 3 to 4 times the day you would need to seek some attention for that. †And then, of course if you notice any blood in your stool, absolutely that's an immediate call to your provider, that would not be normal. So kind of tracking, am I having it more frequently than I have been over the past couple of days and is there any real change in the consistency whether it's becoming all watery or bloody.

Response.BaseQuestion: There's actually evidence that says that physical activity can actually help chemotherapy related fatigue.
Response.Content: It may seem odd, but there's actually evidence that says that physical activity can actually help chemotherapy related fatigue. So it may feel like the last thing you want to do, but getting up, walking around the house, walking to the mailbox, and doing whatever you feel like you're able to do can actually help. Any amount of physical activity is shown to actually help chemotherapy associated fatigue.

Response.BaseQuestion: If it's bothersome to you, or if it's out of the ordinary for you, it needs to be reported.
Response.Content: I have seen more times than I can count, patients who end up admitted to the hospital because they didn't want to bother the provider, the nurse practitioner, whoever is working with them. You know, the bottom line is, if it's bothersome to you or if it's out of the ordinary for you, it needs to be reported. A good rule of thumb is let your healthcare provider decide if it's something that needs to be intervened upon. That should not be on you.

Response.BaseQuestion: It can often become hard to get out of bed and sometimes just getting off of the couch seems like in an enormous task, and that's not normal.
Response.Content: Unfortunately, fatigue is a very common side effect of most chemotherapeutic agents. And it can often become hard just to get out of bed and sometimes just getting off of the couch seems like in an enormous task, and that's not normal. †You will have some degree of energy loss with chemotherapy, but you know, to find yourself challenged to, you know, get out of a chair, go to the bathroom, walk a flight of steps, these are the things that would indicate that perhaps your fatigue is at a higher level than what we would call normal. We can recommend things like energy conservation and trying to kind of group your tasks, so that you can get more prolonged periods of rest throughout the day. †But these are, it's something you want to be aware of, you know if you're finding yourself sleeping more than usual and finding yourself getting short of breath and having chest pain with any type of activity this could be a sign that you are having some level of anemia from your chemotherapy and anemia really does aggravate the chemotherapy associated fatigue that we can see.

Response.BaseQuestion: Sometimes you'll lose color in your face, your eye sockets will actually kind of seem deeper into your face.
Response.Content: Is your skin becoming drier? Sometimes you'll lose color in your face, your eye sockets will actually kind of seem deeper into your face. Your mucous membranes will become dry. These are all things that would indicate that you are becoming dehydrated from the level of vomiting or unable to take anything in and you'd want to call your healthcare provider.

Response.BaseQuestion: It's very important to track anything you experience once you start these drugs.
Response.Content: It's very important to track anything you experience once you start these drugs. I very often will recommend keeping some kind of diary, whether it's electronic or on paper. You know, what did you experience today? How many times did you have to use the bathroom? What were you able to eat or drink? So that you can kind of track and see, you know, how do I feel this day versus the next day? But it's very important to be aware of how your body's responding to the drugs that you're on, so that you can seek care at the earliest point possible if intervention needs to be taken.

Response.BaseQuestion: Fatigue can actually aggravate some of the other side effects of chemotherapy such as nausea and vomiting, depression.
Response.Content: Fatigue can quickly interfere with your quality-of-life. Fatigue, overwhelming fatigue, can be a sign that maybe dose modifications need to be made.
