But you know, fatigue can actually, is shown to aggravate some of the other side effects of chemotherapy such as nausea and vomiting, depression. A lot of times people want to say, well you know, I'm on chemotherapy I'm supposed to be tired I'm supposed to be fatigued. Not to the degree that it's interfering with your quality-of-life or possibly aggravating other symptoms. So never hesitate to talk with your healthcare provider about that. There may be another physical reason in addition to side effects. Like I said, you could have some level of anemia or something that we can do to correct that to improve your energy level.

Response.BaseQuestion: I would also suggest leaning on your family and caregiver support system.
Response.Content: I would also suggest leaning on your family and caregiver support system. Involving them in the psychosocial issues you're needing to cope with and seeking support from them. Support from patients going through similar treatments, patients who are at varying stages of the cancer trajectory. Ranging from maybe just starting treatment like they are, all the way through to beating the disease and in the survivorship stage. Seeking support groups, whether in person, there are a variety of online support groups. Now there is no shortage of support groups that can help.

Response.BaseQuestion: Constipation can be just as problematic as diarrhea when you're on chemotherapy.
Response.Content: Constipation can be just as problematic as diarrhea when you're on chemotherapy and something to also alert your healthcare provider if you're experiencing severe constipation things like abdominal cramping. †Some of the strategies you can take will obviously you know promote a bowel regimen things like a softener or laxative can be pretty mild not a lot of side effects and often times very effective in helping chemotherapy related constipation. Increasing your oral intake can certainly help. Increasing mobility can help with constipation. So these are all things that you can do on your own to try to help alleviate some of the constipation, but it's just as important to make sure you're talking to your healthcare provider about the possibility of needing a bowel regimen and when to seek attention. Because there are some chemotherapeutic agents that can cause obstruction, so it's not something you want to overlook. So an obstruction would be almost like a fecal impaction and you become so constipated and full of stool that you can have a back-up through the gastrointestinal system and it can cause some pretty serious complications within your small bowel or large bowel. It can often require hospitalization while we have to what we called decompress the bowel, so all that to say, it's not something that you want to take lightly. It's important to know what your normal is, so that if you notice a change from your normal bowel movement patterns you can discuss that with your healthcare provider.

Response.BaseQuestion: It's very important to stick to the schedule that your healthcare provider gives you for your pain medications.
Response.Content: One of the most common mistakes I can see is when somebody, a patient, maybe is not experiencing pain and they think I don't really need my opioids. I don't need to take my pain medications. Having a great day, don't need it and then they actually will experience pain pretty severely after taking a little break from the pain medication. †So it's very important to stick to the schedule that your healthcare provider gives you for your pain medications to keep your pain at bay, regardless of your pain level. Of course, if you experience an increase in pain and you're noticing that the medications aren't as effective you'll want to check in with your healthcare provider and make the adjustments necessary. But very important to stay on the schedule that you're healthcare provider gives you.

Response.BaseQuestion: I really can't stress enough how important it is if you're on any type of oral chemotherapy to fairly regularly take a look at your skin.
Response.Content: Skin issues while on oral agents for chemotherapy become very important. There are some chemotherapy drugs with which rashes and skin changes can be expected and in some cases mean that the drug is actually working. That's just some agents. So any rashes, any new skin reactions that you notice really should be directed, brought to the attention of your healthcare provider so that decisions can be made about the proper topical treatment, if necessary, any breaks in the drug that might be required. So I really can't stress enough how important it is if you're on any type of oral chemotherapy to fairly regularly take a look at your skin. Even the parts that maybe you can't see, on the back. And be aware of any changes, any new rashes and to let your healthcare provider know about them as soon as you notice them. Sometimes they can become so irritating and so debilitating that patients will sometimes just stop taking them because they're just so irritated, but then we can see, you know that possibly that was an indication of that the drug was working and it is very important when you're on oral agents to really adhere to the prescribed frequency. And any changes from that can really have an impact on the efficacy of the drug, so really letting the decision to hold or change doses really be up to your treating physician.

Response.BaseQuestion: With chemotherapy it's really important to take good care of the skin.
Response.Content: With chemotherapy it's really important to take good care of the skin in general. †Keep the skin clean and moisturized. If you go into the sun make sure that you're wearing a good sunscreen, but it's also important that if a rash becomes significant to the point where it's bothering a patient and making them not want to take their chemo anymore that they're in touch with their healthcare provider. And this is extremely important because they found actually a relationship between certain types of chemotherapy and the presence of a rash. In other words the rash says that it's working to a certain degree with some types of chemo, so to let the healthcare provider know what you're experiencing but not necessarily stop or change your drug prescription in any way without their permission and their guidance.

Response.BaseQuestion: It's important to ensure that even if you do have some Microsites or some sores in the mouth continue to eat and drink normally.
Response.Content: Chemotherapy can kill off the rapidly dividing cells in the mouth and along the G.I. tract and it's important to keep the mouth clean and moist. Rinsing with just some water or some weak saline, just a teaspoon of salt in a cup of water for example, is the least expensive very easy fix. To just rinse and spit on a regular basis, say four times the day. Keeping your teeth brushed, but not overly so. You don't want your gums to bleed or anything along that line. It's okay to floss as long as your platelet count and your white blood cell count are not in a dangerous zone and to probably avoid spicy foods a lot of times or anything really salty that would cause even more discomfort in the oral cavity. Mucositis can get very severe, but it really depends on the type of treatment that someone receives. Certain chemotherapies do tend to cause just a small sore in the mouth like somebody would describe it as a canker sore something simple like that which can still be painful and bothersome, but not necessarily keep someone from eating normally and drinking normally. It's important to ensure that even if you do have some mucositis or some sores in the mouth continue to eat and drink normally. If you're not able to eat and drink fully contact the healthcare provider because that's when you need to make sure that you got enough fluid so you're not becoming dehydrated.

Response.BaseQuestion: Write everything down because you're not going to remember it whether it's due to stress or chemotherapy.
Response.Content: A lot of patients do complain of memory loss and forgetfulness and not necessarily confusion, but they just don't feel like they have their full selves there. A lot of times it's attributed to stress and lack of sleep, fatigue in general. All of that can occur. You can also have some changes within the brain from the chemotherapy itself, but every person is a little bit different and people use a lot of different tricks to help them remember things. A lot of people will write notes and have Post its all over the place. And to make sure they write things down when you go to the doctor's office or when you're visiting or calling your healthcare provider. Write everything down because you're not going to remember it whether it's due to stress or chemotherapy. It's very common to forget things frequently.

Response.BaseQuestion: Make sure that you've got a nice routine that you can go to sleep the same way every evening.
Response.Content: Many people have sleep disturbances and they can be related again to the stress of overall treatment and the stress of life when you're trying to go through treatment. To provide what they call sleep hygiene, providing a darkened room to sleep that's a little bit on the cooler side will help some people. Making sure that you get some exercise, some fresh air during the day. Try not to watch TV before going to sleep or anything that will kind of keep the brain busy before you go to sleep. Make sure that you've got a nice routine that you can go to sleep the same way every evening.

Response.BaseQuestion: If there's anything that's keeping someone from taking their medications as prescribed it really does need to be communicated to the healthcare team.
Response.Content: One of the most important things about taking oral anti-cancer drugs is to make sure that they're actually taken as prescribed. It's sometimes very challenging to get the drugs from the pharmacy initially because many of the pharmacies, many of the drugs, need to be ordered from specialty pharmacies and they might be received in the mail rather than just picking it up at your local store as you would with the rest of the prescriptions. †But it's extremely important if you don't get them when you're supposed to, notify the healthcare team. †And if there's anything that's keeping someone from taking their medications as prescribed it really does need to be communicated to the healthcare team. The way that the oral chemotherapies work is they build up a certain blood level of the drug and that's what's effective against the cancer and to skip a dose or to try to double up if you skipped a dose anything like that will actually cause more harm than good. †So it's really very, very important to always take the chemotherapy drugs on schedule as prescribed. If they need to be taken with food for example or without food for example make sure you have those instructions ahead of time so that can be so you can follow the instructions as, as you were given and if there's something if something happens to prevent you from taking it as prescribed you should notify the prescriber to make sure that they know how much you've taken and why things might be changing.

Response.BaseQuestion: When you do find that healthcare provider you are comfortable speaking with remember that they have heard it before.
Response.Content: The Loss of sexual desire after chemotherapy is a common side effect and it can be quite difficult to converse with your healthcare provider about that issue. My advice would be to be open, to be honest. Find a Healthcare provider that you're comfortable talking to, whether it is male or female, and openly discuss your issues so they can help you to the best of their ability. When you do find that healthcare provider you are comfortable speaking with remember that they have heard it before and they will be doing their best to find the best outcome for you. One other suggestion I would make is that a lot of oncology practices and centers are offering the ability for patients to email in question so if you're more comfortable with writing your issue instead of discussing it verbally that may be one option for you as well. One thing to remember too is that if you're having a sexual problem following chemotherapy or following radiation treatment whatever it may be chances are someone else has had the same problem and that's why I say healthcare provider will do their best to find you the best outcome. There's also, a good idea is to find a support group that deals with a specific issue or just issues in general where you can discuss the problem, maybe one on one with someone or in a group setting with people that are have these same kind of problems you're having.

Response.BaseQuestion: If you do have a history of any kind of heart problem they can maybe tailor your treatment or monitor you a little more closely for those side effects.
Response.Content: One side effect of some chemotherapy agents, not all of them, can be some cardiac or heart problems. It's very important first of all to let your healthcare provider, your oncologist your nurse know if you have a history of any kind of heart problem because that can compound the issue. And if you do have a history of any kind of heart problem they can maybe tailor your treatment or monitor you a little more closely for those side effects. Some of the problems that can happen can be an irregular heartbeat. Some palpitations, some people refer to them as a murmur. If you have a history of heart failure you probably know what those symptoms are with fluid retention and swelling of your feet and ankles, maybe some cloudiness in your head and of course if you have any type of what you may think of as heart attack symptoms it's very important to call 911 or get to an emergency room right away. Such as chest pain, chest pressure, any pain maybe that will go down your left arm that would be associated in addition to the chest pain or pressure that you might be having, so that's very important to remember.

Response.BaseQuestion: I want to encourage you to do is report any symptoms of tingling, numbness, difficulty buttoning your clothes, difficulty dialing a phone, or difficulty typing on the computer keyboard.
Response.Content: The side effect of peripheral neuropathy can be quite distressing for patients and what I want to encourage you to do is report any symptoms of tingling, numbness, difficulty buttoning your clothes, difficulty dialing a phone, difficulty typing on the computer keyboard. †Those are very important symptoms that could potentially point to peripheral neuropathy and that you need to let your healthcare provider know. It may affect your treatment dose your treatment dose may need to be reduced or may not but they need to keep monitoring the symptoms and you need to keep reporting them. It's important not to hide those because you think your dose might be reduced because of them because they can get worse. So you need to make sure that you keep on top of them and report them to your healthcare provider. One thing about peripheral neuropathy that it's important to remember is that it can be reversible or can be irreversible. †If it is irreversible it may be permanent for the rest of your life, so it is something monitor, something to watch as you move through your survivorship days because you could have difficulty in feeling temperature changes that's something that's very important when you're taking a bath, when you're taking a shower, when you're washing dishes, when you doing laundry, when you're shoveling snow. The hot and cold temperatures can make a difference and you could actually have some damage to your skin because you may not feel the temperature change because of the peripheral neuropathy. It can also cause a lot of pain, it can also cause tingling and numbness to come and go and your fingers your toes really any of your extremities arms legs. †So it's important again to monitor those and report those to your healthcare provider whether it be your primary care physician or your oncologist.

Response.BaseQuestion: You know your vision best. You know what your body is usually like and any change in your vision, any change in how your eyes feel, you need to report those.
Response.Content: Some chemotherapy treatments and other cancer treatments can affect your eyes and some changes you might see could be dry eyes or it could be the opposite. You could have excessive tearing, you could also have maybe some blurred vision, so it's important to monitor that and you know yourself best. You know your vision best. You know what your body is usually like and any change in your vision, any change in how your eyes feel, you need to report those. Sometimes you can treat them on your own. Dry eyes, you can try artificial tears. †But it can be a problem that goes beyond what artificial tears or something else might be able to do. So you would need to contact your physician. Maybe they would recommend going to see an eye doctor about that problem, but again important to contact your healthcare provider if it's something that's very bothersome and you're unable to control or treat on your own.

Response.BaseQuestion: First and foremost, when you're taking oral chemotherapy you should ask if there's any restrictions to your diet to make sure there's no contraindications.
Response.Content: As far as eating and drinking and making sure your dietary components are where they should be. First and foremost, when you're taking oral chemotherapy you should ask if there's any restrictions to your diet to make sure there's no contraindications, meaning there might be a certain food or drink or supplement that you're taking that might interfere with your treatment. So you want to make sure that there's nothing you usually eat, drink or take that might interfere with your treatment and cause it to maybe have more side effects or to maybe even not work as well as it should work. †That's important. †It's also very important to keep up your nutritional status. There is usually, if not always, some way to get hold of a dietician or a nutritionist through your oncologist office. They should all have a contact with a nutritionist or dietician and they can help you with meal planning if you are concerned about eating too much or that you've been eating too little. They can help you with supplements, meaning the liquid supplements for extra calories or maybe even to help you to round out your diet if it is missing something because you are unable to take in certain nutrients that you might need.

Response.BaseQuestion: Look into getting a referral to a cosmetologist who works with cancer patients who can help you with selecting a wig.
Response.Content: One concern or fear of chemotherapy is loss of hair and many times this affects women differently than man. †What's important is to ask before you start your treatment if this will cause hair loss, if you're treatment will cause hair loss and what type of hair loss that will cause. Sometimes it's partial; sometimes it's full hair loss, and if that's a concern to you, you, need to ask for, or look into getting a referral to a cosmetologist who works with cancer patients who can help you with selecting a wig, making changes to that wig to make it look as much like your hair as possible. †If a cosmetologist is not an option for you, maybe financially, the American Cancer Society or maybe another organization that offers hair prosthesis, as they call them, or wigs to cancer patients would be an option for you. Many times those services are free. They may not have a high-level cosmetologist available to help you, but at least it would be a start for you and you wouldn't have to go without some kind of hair covering or wig or prosthesis whatever you want to call it throughout your treatment that you would get some support you would get some help with that and always remember your hair is going to grow back. †And the regrowth of your hair, when it happens, will usually start maybe a month or so after your treatment finishes sometimes patients even have a little bit to regrowth in between treatments and sometimes your hair can be completely different when it grows back. For instance, if you used to color your hair and you know you had some grey hair it's probably going to come in pretty gray or it could come back curly when you really had straight hair before. Most of the time that texture goes back to normal at some point once your hair really starts coming back in but not always so there can be a change in texture change in color and be aware that it may look quite different than your previous head of hair. When you'll lose your hair will vary depending on the treatment that you're taking sometimes it will fall out within a week or so the first treatment sometimes it takes three or four weeks sometimes it's with the second and third treatment cycle of treatment month of treatment before you'll see much hair loss at all and again not every drug will cause hair loss.

Response.BaseQuestion: If you have a more sedentary lifestyle or you're more inactive because maybe you're experiencing some fatigue it's still important to get some exercise.
Response.Content: Sometimes chemotherapy patients may develop blood clots in their legs and this is can be a very serious side effect or very serious complication of treatment, so it's important to know the signs and symptoms and know how to prevent them. Prevention, keep active, don't stay sedentary, however if you do start feeling some pain in your legs, some pressure in your leg, noticed some swelling in your leg or both legs that would be an indication that you need to contact your physician. Especially if it's swelling that doesn't go away. If its pain that doesn't go away when you sit down and elevate your legs and that would be another way to determine if it's really important to call your physician is If you do sit down and elevate your leg and the pain doesn't go away, the swelling doesn't go away. If you have a more sedentary lifestyle or you're more inactive because maybe you're experiencing some fatigue it's still important to get some exercise whether it be if you're lying in bed you can roll your ankles around, you can lift your feet up and down, you can move them around just to keep your circulation going very well. †If you're traveling whether it be in the car, whether it be in a plane, it's important, if you're driving a car to take some frequent rest stops get up walk around and keep that circulation going. On the plane you can sit in your seat and again lift your legs, roll your ankles, extend your feet up and down and that will be very helpful in preventing swelling as well as a blood clot or thrombosis as it's called.

Response.BaseQuestion: Communicating with your healthcare provider about any issues or concerns or just any questions you may have is extremely important.
Response.Content: Communicating with your healthcare provider about any issues or concerns or just any questions you may have is extremely important. Maybe something you forgot to ask during an appointment comes into your head and one thing to ask or to remember is that most oncology offices at this point have some way to electronically contact patients. Whether it be through an email address, a text message system, even just a phone call to the nurses. And many of them have 24-hour availability to be able to contact. I'm not saying that you should contact them with every little question, but it is an option if you forget to ask something, if you have a real concern, if you're not sure if you should come in for an appointment. That's a really good way to get a hold of them and ask out right, "Here's what's happening, Do I need to come do I not need to come in." And you'd probably get a faster response that way than calling in and waiting for a call back later in the day or the following day.

Response.BaseQuestion: Cancer care is an expensive disease.
Response.Content: Cancer care is an expensive disease and it's in the headlines quite a bit in terms of the rapidly rising cost, not only in terms of treatment costs, but the out-of-pocket costs for families. This is particularly acute in terms of oral agents and that is getting much more attention. The way in which coverage pays for medications differs between intravenous therapy the patients will receive in the hospital, or in their physician's office, or an infusion center, versus getting a pill, which they will be able to take at home. And there is a discrepancy between those costs and the oral agents. Many of them today are quite expensive. They can be tens of thousands of dollars, in fact some can be as much a hundred thousand dollars a year, and that's partly related to the reimbursement for those medications.

Response.BaseQuestion: The way in which chemotherapy medications are covered in insurance plans varies. And because of that we are finding issues with patients continuing to take their oral medications.
Response.Content: The way in which chemotherapy medications are covered in insurance plans varies. And, because of that we are finding issues with patients continuing to take their oral medications. Because oral medications are under the prescription plan of the plan. So, if you think about Medicare, Medicare Part D is the prescription plan that people who are eligible for Medicare subscribe to. Depending on the plan which a person chooses when they become a patient can make a difference in terms of how much they are going to be responsible for paying. Again in the case of Medicare, Medicare Part A is the hospital coverage. Medicare Part B is the physician or the outpatient coverage. And that's where the drugs that are given intravenously are administered. And, there, again there's co-pay there, but there's much better coverage in those cases. That is also true with other kinds of insurance. Certainly people who are under 25 develop cancer and have treatment for cancer and some of the cancers they have are being treated more and more with what we call oral agents, with pills, and that is causing more hardship for families in terms of what they're responsible for paying.

Response.BaseQuestion: They're having to make very difficult financial decisions.
Response.Content: You know something that nurses hear quite regularly from patients when they are prescribed oral agents and learn what those, the cost of those agents are going to be, is that they're facing choices. While there may be the convenience of having a pill and not having to go to a cancer center or a physician, hospital, a physician practice or a hospital, they are often faced with, "If I have to pay this amount for this drug, what is it going to do to my grocery budget? What is that going to do to my mortgage payment or my rent or any of the other routine expenses that we have in our daily life?" And, so patients often are faced with those difficult decisions. Some may make the decision that they are going to use up their savings for retirement or that are taking care of them in retirement. Some may borrow against any of retirement plans they have. They're having to make very difficult financial decisions.

Response.BaseQuestion: If the oral agent is really equivalent to the infusion agent and in terms of efficacy and outcome, the decision maybe then to continue the intravenous agent although there is an oral agent alternative.
Response.Content: Well, Medicare choosing is certainly a challenge in terms of Medicare Part D. I think Medicare Part A and B often times the patient really is choosing between traditional Medicare, or the Medicare Advantage programs. But when it comes to the prescription plan, the Medicare Part D, there are any number of options that the patients have. And, each option may cover different things. And at the time that a person is choosing those plans they may not have a cancer diagnosis, and so when they look at what the premium will be for that Part D, they may not be thinking in terms of the what if; "What if I have cancer?" And, certainly may choose a low-cost plan that has limited formulary, limited list of medications. And, then once they have a diagnosis of cancer they may even find that from year-to-year they may have to look very carefully because even if this year's choice has their drug on the list, next year's choice may not. And, they may have to switch to a different plan. So, once they have a cancer diagnosis, if they are on oral agents, they have to look very carefully at the Part D plans. So let's take the example of somebody who has been on intravenous chemotherapy and is now being changed to an oral agent. They may have been, they would probably have been, being covered under Medicare because of part A or B, depending on whether they were getting the chemo in the hospital or in a physician's infusion practice. But, if it's now an oral agent, they may be part way into their Part D insurance coverage, and the agent that the physician wants to move them to may not be covered. That does lead to some interesting dilemmas as well. Because if the oral agent is really equivalent to the infusion agent and in terms of efficacy and outcome, the decision maybe then to continue the intravenous agent, although there is an oral agent alternative.

Response.BaseQuestion: While there still is somewhat of a donut hole, that is closing and it will continue to close
Response.Content: You know one of the things that, certainly in the earliest years of Medicare Part D, that was quite a shock, I think, to many seniors who went on Part D was the infamous donut hole. And while there still is somewhat of a donut hole, that is closing and it will continue to close, but that was a combination of reaching your limit of deductible, reaching a certain amount in terms of your co-pays, and then in the donut hole you will be uncovered, and then having to get to another total expenditure to get coverage again. So it was a certain amount of coverage and your own expense and then going basically uncovered for a period of time and then back to coverage.

Response.BaseQuestion: Those plans can help fill-in where that the Medicare plans are not covering
Response.Content: Medigap plans are plans, that again, people can purchase. They have a premium associated with them, so there is cost, but those plans can help fill in where the Medicare plans are not covering.

Response.BaseQuestion: Medicare may not pay at all for those medications if they're off label use.
Response.Content: In cancer care it's not unusual that a cancer drug, which often times these drugs take 17 years to get from discovery to when they are available as a standard treatment, and so when people are, when the FDA approves, when the FDA approves a drug by the time it gets to the point from that discovery to being approved as standard treatment, typically it's then for a limited disease or a limited number of diseases. But, what we know is that sometimes these drugs are beneficial in other cancers, but those cancers have not been part of a clinical trial and the clinical trial part of this whole development of drugs is very important in leading into the FDA approval. So, now we may have a situation where a physician feels a particular drug or combination of drugs would be beneficial for a certain patient with a certain disease and those drugs are not on label use, it can be very beneficial, but Medicare may not pay at all for those medications, if they're off label use. That's also true of other payers. In fact, it's not uncommon with other payers because they look at this and think, "Well it's an experimental use," and they don't look at it as the standard and don't look at it as being covered.

Response.BaseQuestion: There is a bill in Congress it has not been passed and what we know is until that's passed the true impact is not going to be felt.
Response.Content: Over the last few years, particularly as we see an increase number of oral agents be developed and come onto the market, the issue of parity with intravenous chemotherapy has become, and because of the cost of the oral agents, this has become quite a policy and political issue, both at the national as well as at the state level. We have many many states that have, probably over half of our states, have approved parity which says if an insurance plan covers intravenous drugs it should also be covering, equitably, the oral agent as well. The federal law has not passed. There is a law, there is a bill in Congress. It has not been passed, and what we know is until that's passed really true impact is not going to be felt. Because, the states, what they regulate, it doesn't impact the largest payer in this country which is Medicare. And, many of the private payers follow, then, the Medicare lead. So, the national bill, if that gets approved, will be very important to watch then what happens.

Response.BaseQuestion: Let the healthcare team know that they're struggling in terms of financial impact of the treatment.
Response.Content: You know if patients are in a situation where they find themselves struggling in terms of the cost of their cancer treatment. Particularly if it's an oral agent, they should not try to solve that by themselves by cutting the pill in half or taking it less frequently or stopping some other medication. The first thing that the patient should do is address this when they go in for a visit, or, if they're not scheduled for a visit, to make a visit to let the healthcare team know that they're struggling in terms of financial impact of the treatment. And, to work with the healthcare team on what possible solutions there are, whether that might be submitting an application for support from a pharmaceutical agent, whether it's looking at their whole medication profile and looking; do they happen to have the option for generics and some other kinds of medicines that might be lower-cost? But, they shouldn't try and solve it themselves by anything that would alter the way in which the medication was prescribed because they won't get the benefit from the treatment. You know many of the pharmaceutical companies are recognizing, and they have for years, that with the cost of treatment there might be patients who are unable to pay for the treatments that they need and that it would be tremendously beneficial to them. So, many of the pharmaceutical companies have programs with reduced cost of access for the medications. And, there's a process and the process begins with the provider and, whether it's in the physician's office or the hospital-based clinic, and an appeal; basically an application process to the particular pharmaceutical company that provides the drug, in that they process that, and it's needs based so there is an application that has to occur.

Response.BaseQuestion: Things like risk for infection, gastrointestinal side effects, these can all be relatively normal or relatively expected side effects
Response.Content: Well, there are such a variety of side effects we can see with oral agents. Some of the most common that you might see, Myelosuppression, or causing your bone marrow to not make normal cells or the amount that they normally would make. So things that you can see from that are your white blood cell counts can drop. Your white blood cells are what fight infection, so we can see patients become very prone to infection as they're on any type of chemotherapy including oral agents. Becomes very important to monitor if you're having a fever, and let your healthcare provider know as soon as you start to experience a possible even low-grade fever. Usually our cut off is around 100.4. You can also see, as your platelet counts drop, some bruising. You can bleed more easily than you normally would. Also, things to let your healthcare provider know about. Gastrointestinal side effects can be just as common with oral agents so things like nausea, vomiting, diarrhea you'd want to let your healthcare provider know. If you're not able to take anything in orally either food or beverage. That's not normal. You need to be able to keep some degree of food or beverages down. Diarrhea. Good thing to talk to your healthcare provider about. We usually track it in terms of how frequently you're going every day and what would a normal increase in that be. Along the lines of gastrointestinal side effects, we can see mouth sores that are a portal of entry for bacteria, can cause infections, painful swallowing, all of these things are common side effects, but ones that would require letting your healthcare provider know about. So things like risk for infection, gastrointestinal side effects, these can all be relatively normal or relatively expected side effects. Skin reactions. We can see rashes develop pretty much anywhere but especially the hands and feet. That would also be something you let healthcare provider know about.

Response.BaseQuestion: I think part of it was psychological because I knew I was putting, in my mind; poison into my body.
Response.Content: I felt somewhat unprepared to take this oral med. And I started off with three pills in the morning, three pills in the evening. And the pills are like these monster, to me in my mind, seem like these monstrous, and I would choke on them when I was trying to take them. I think part of it was psychological because I knew I was putting, in my mind; poison into my body and so that took a while to get adjusted to. When I asked, "Does it come in a liquid form, can I do anything else?" They said, "No it's only this horse pill, that there is nothing we can change." I guess part of it is just suck it up and take it. I know this sounds harsh, but it's the only thing right now keeping my cancer from growing, so I just take my time and I take one at a time. And I think some of it is psychological, but I think there is a true physical component to it. They're bigger pills and it's hard for me to swallow them. So it's gotten better. It's gotten a lot better because I think I've come to realize in my head that, "Liz, they can't change anything and they can't give it to you in a liquid form you just have to suck it up."

Response.BaseQuestion: Even though it's tough to take it, I feel good about taking it.
Response.Content: With the IV you are just so sick and I took pills to have handle the nausea. I was on all these different things and I ended up in the hospital for eight days because I had all kinds of side effects, and my pressure was low, and I mean it was really a nightmare. So I knew I didn't want to go back on the IV stuff if at all possible. If he would have said, "Look, you need another round of IV," I would have whined about it, but I would have gotten it, but that's not the case. It was very attractive to me that there was the option of using an oral chemo drug, so even though it's tough to take it, I feel good about taking it and I would hope that others are able to see the powerful chemo drug but you're not getting all the side effects that you get from the IV chemotherapy.

Response.BaseQuestion: I actually went to the website for the drug and looked a lot of stuff up there.
Response.Content: The way I found out about a lot of the information related to the oral drug I am taking was the Internet. You have to distinguish between what's fact and what a bunch of baloney that's out there, so you have to be really careful when you look at these websites. I actually went to the website for the drug and looked a lot of stuff up there. When I was with my first oncologist and she suggested this oral drug, they gave me like a packet of information and that sort of thing. She didn't really explain anything, but she gave me the packet of information to take home and look through it. I really wasn't given many instructions. My caregiver, my husband, he did some research on the internet as well, plus the little fold out paper that you get with the drug, there's a lot of information there. And you know that it's decent information because if it was false, hopefully, it wouldn't be in that little paper that comes with it. So I read through that. Some of my colleagues at work explained to me a little about the drug, and about how you have to store it, and I have to be careful with it. Do a lot of it, I think, I learned on my own.

Response.BaseQuestion: I really found relief from the pity parties. While I still have them, they're not nearly as drastic as they were in the past.
Response.Content: I have had some times where I feel really sad, and I feel sorry for myself and don't want to get out of bed and that sort of thing. But the physician put me on an antidepressant and that has helped tremendously. Again, I don't feel like I'm crazy, or I'm going to go out and do something crazy. But I think it's just enough to help me deal with the emotional roller coaster. Because that's what it is, really. One minute you're happy and you've done everything you could, and then the next minute bam something slams into your face and all of a sudden you have a whole new battle which, that was that was very, very hard for me to adjust to that new battle each time it's happened. I would definitely encourage other patients to consider using an antidepressant, and I think there are a lot of negative comments about, "Well you must be crazy." "You're on an antidepressant." And that's not the case. I really found relief from the pity parties. While I still have them, they're not nearly as drastic as they were in the past. So I think it's a good thing to go on this. Nobody needs to know that you're taking it, well except the whole world now that I'm saying it. You can take the drug without feeling; you should be able to take the drug without feeling guilty, and it's helped me immensely. And it's actually okay to have some pity parties because there are times where you just want to, "Forget it, I'm not doing this anymore I just want to go back to my old life." Well that's never going to happen, so the fact that I have to take this drug more than likely the rest of my life, I just have to get used to that change.

Response.BaseQuestion: I am very, very blessed to, number one have a fantastic family who has helped me immensely.
Response.Content: From a social standpoint I am very, very blessed to number one have a fantastic family who has helped me immensely. My son makes me breakfast, or he'll make me something for lunch when he's not at work. I mean they've been tremendous. I've also had a lot of friends that have sent cards and books and scarves, and it's been really wonderful to see who your friends really are. Because when something this drastic happens, I've one friend that I haven't heard from the entire time, and she knows what's going on because I put the stuff on Facebook and I haven't heard from her at all. And I was really, really disappointed by that. But again it just shows you who you can count on and who you can't. I know who I can count on. I also use a service that I can I can post an update on what I'm doing and then my friends will subscribe to that website or webpage. I'm not sure exactly how it works, but when I send an update it goes out to everybody that subscribed because I don't really want to get on the phone and talk to a hundred people. I want to tell one person and that person can kind of divide up the story. And that's helped a lot.

Response.BaseQuestion: There may be a little things that nobody picks up that that nurse will see and then go back to the physician and sale I'm concerned because Liz has this this and this going on.
Response.Content: I would suggest to other patients that are going through this that communication is really the key because sometimes what happens is you're seeing so many doctors and you're doing silly things it's really hard to keep all that straight. And sometimes the doctor will come in and say okay you have this this and this and walk out the door. It's the nurse, again my experience, it's the nurses who are the ones actually sit down with you and say, "Okay here's what you should do, take this. If you start to feel nauseous take this anti-nausea drug." And she is the one that explains a lot of things to me. So communicating back to your physician and having the physician or most in most cases be the nurse are the ones then will call you to check in, "Hey I know you started this new medicine. How are you feeling? Do you need anything else?" If I need something related to insurance, bam, she's first person I call. If I have major side effects that I don't think I can deal with on my own, I call her and it can be anytime, weekends, middle of the night. There are ones that you can ask questions about that want to give you the reassurance that you need, and they're the ones that will relay information back to the physician and then once she's talking to the physician. And once she talks to the physician, she then relays that information to me. There may be a little things that nobody picks up that that nurse will see and then go back to the physician and say, I'm concerned because Liz has this, this and this going on. And so then there's the communication between the nurse and me, between the nurse and the physician, and then between physician and me, so we can have a threesome going there.

Response.BaseQuestion: It can just be sensitive or it can evolve into some blisters that are actually noticeable blisters and they can be quite painful.
Response.Content: Certain types of chemotherapy, oral chemotherapy and intravenous chemotherapy can cause something called hand- foot syndrome. And that can be just some sensitive areas around the palms of the hands or the soles of the feet and it can just be sensitive or it can evolve into some blisters that are actually noticeable blisters and they can be quite painful. Keeping the hands clean, moist and the soles of the feet clean and moist, again with just a regular moisturizer, it doesn't have to be anything fancy. And try to avoid anything constricting. No tight shoes, no tight gloves. Let the circulation in that area flow freely.

Response.BaseQuestion: It was cold. It was winter, so I wore a lot of hats.
Response.Content: Well, when I lost my hair for the first round of chemo. It was cold. It was winter, so I wore a lot of hats. I wore the scarf once in a while. But I thought about the whole wig thing, but then I thought well this is going to be over soon and I don't really need to pay 500 hundred dollars for a wig that I might never use. So I didn't go and get one, although people had given me information about where you could go, who you could talk to, that sort of thing. I decided I didn't need it. I had these hats on. My daughter was a student at Penn State. I had this Penn State hat which was pretty silly looking. It had these fake braid things that come down. That thing was the warmest thing I ever wore. I wore it around the house. I wore it when I went out. I always had this dang thing on, but it was so warm. It came down over my ears and, because you're right, when you lose your hair you're freezing all the time. Especially, as they say with babies they lose a lot of heat through their scalp, well adult patients do too, and I was just cold all the time. When my hair grew back in, it was this dark color because this is my natural color, this brown. So many people knew me as a blond because I had highlights in my hair for quite a while. So as people were seeing me for the first time like, "holy cow you have brown hair." "Yeah, it's kind of what I was born with, the brown hair." Then I had a whole bunch of grey hair in the front. I let it grown in to the point I couldn't take it. "Get this grey out of here. Dye it, do whatever you need to do." So she colored my hair my natural color, but got all that grey, which is starting to come back, don't tell anybody, but that was very, very helpful. When my hair started growing back it was these little ringlet curls and I used to pay big money when I had big hair back in the 80s to get my hair permed. Well, this I don't know if you can tell, it's all natural curl, it grew in with all these curls. "Wow, this is amazing." So I was quite surprised by that.

Response.BaseQuestion: You're just overwhelmed. If you do three things then you have to sit down and take a rest.
Response.Content: Mr. F., Fatigue. That sucker is always with me it feels like. When I was on the chemo IV, I was tired; but I wasn't really doing a whole lot to feel exhausted. Now that I'm on the oral drug I'm doing more and it's this feeling of complete exhaustion. Like I will be sitting there looking at something on email and I'll fall asleep or I'll be reading the newspaper and I'll fall sleep. I mean it's just, it's overwhelming. Yesterday I didn't get out of bed till noon and I slept that whole time. It wasn't like I went back to bed or anything like that, and I had a very sound sleep until I looked at the clock and I'm like, "Oh my god it's noon I've got to get up." So I think that between the nausea and the fatigue, those are probably the two biggest things that... I was afraid of the nausea because I didn't want to be throwing up all the time, so I would take these pills to make it so I don't throw up. The fatigue is just... You're just overwhelmed. If you do three things then you have to sit down and take a rest. Like most of the time I would take a nap in the afternoon and I was never a nap person and at first it was. "Oh Liz, if you take a nap you'll never sleep at night you shouldn't do that." Where I could take a nap and still sleep eight hours a night.

Response.BaseQuestion: At first I was like "are you kidding me?" I'm tired why would I want to go for a walk?
Response.Content: What did I do for the fatigue, well I started walking which the Oncology Nursing Society has a lot of information about how exercise whatever you choose to do, walk, treadmill, whatever happens to be really, really helps with the fatigue. At first I was like "are you kidding me", I'm tired why would I want to go for a walk that just doesn't sound right. But before I started, in the interim where I wasn't on any chemo drugs I started to walk and I was up to 5 miles a day which I didn't walk that much when I was healthy so it was really, really exciting to be able to walk that far. Once all the other stuff started going on, the drain and all that business, I haven't been walking as far, but I'm walking a little bit and I keep track of it on my fit bit so that way I can see how many steps I've taken how many miles I've walked and that sort of thing. And actually walking for as much as I hate when they're right it actually did help with fatigue it was still there but it wasn't as intense. For instance yesterday I was I was really, really dizzy and I didn't want to go on a walk if I was ready to pass out, so my husband went with me the day before and yesterday I just I couldn't go anywhere I was just way too tired, but today I'm at work and so far so good I haven't fallen asleep anywhere. I was in a meeting a couple months ago with my CEO and some of the other staff. We have this basic meeting and I kept falling asleep and it's only an hour meeting. I could not stay awake and people said to me "Liz we can't stay awake and we're not on anything else". And the CEO was looking right at me, like oh my God she knows I'm falling asleep and I have to listen. Well then the next meeting I volunteered to be the scribe. So that forced me to stand up, which forced me to stay awake, so I think you find ways. Each person is different, so what may be helpful for me isn't necessarily helpful for another patient that has cancer, but you kind of have to have base it on, well I've tried this and it doesn't really work let's try something else.

Response.BaseQuestion: It really made a difference for me psychologically to be able to get out of bed, get up early, put my big girl clothes on and go to work.
Response.Content: For me going back to work is very, very positive, because my work was my normal life. You know I get up, go to work all day, drive home and you're done. And being at the office makes me feel quote "normal", that I don't have cancer. I don't have to take a million pills because I take them at home. I don't have to take anything here. And it really made a difference for me psychologically to be able to get out of bed, get up early, put my big girl clothes on and go to work. Even at home, like when my kids graduated from college I was able to go to their graduations and not be as worried about fatigue because they were just so happy to see me there. And I barely had any hair at one point and we're taking pictures. Again it's that normal that I would've done even if I wasn't sick, to go and watch my kids graduate from college. It's a good feeling to be at work. There are a lot of people here that have been extremely supportive of me and they even, when I come in to the office, oh everybody comes and, "Liz you look so great" and they give me hugs and to me that is so, so valuable.

Response.BaseQuestion: It depends on what kind of a relationship you have with your coworkers.
Response.Content: Would I recommend telling co-workers? I think in my situation, yes I would. It depends on what kind of a relationship you have with your coworkers. I think for me it's been so positive because people have been very, very supportive. Now if you work in an environment that really doesn't support the whole "you're sick and you're going to miss time" then it might not a good idea to share too much with your employer especially if that person or group isn't providing anything positive to you. So I think, it's, I think it's hit or miss. If you if you think that you can tell people at work, if you think that'll make it easier for you, then you might want to consider that. If you don't feel comfortable talking to somebody at work then maybe you can go to a psychologist. Again it's not bad to do that. I've gone once I haven't got back yet, but again, it's kind of this third-party that doesn't know anything about you that you can just go get your feelings out express what your concerns are and really take care of you as a person and not just of the disease.

Response.BaseQuestion: It was more an inconvenience at times because I wanted to go for a walk, but I couldn't because my feet were so sore.
Response.Content: With the oral drug though there are some side effects. With this particular drug you get blisters on your feet, and I won't show my feet cause they are disgusting looking. You get blisters on your feet, and you get like you're the ball of your foot and your heel get really sensitive and it makes it hard to walk because you have pain, and it's not traditional neuropathy, but it's very, very close to that. My hands have been fine, again knock on wood. I haven't had any kind of ulcers†or anything like that. So, for my feet they recommend that you put lotion on five times a day. I don't have time for that. So I put it on whenever I think about it. It's usually in the morning after I take a shower and at night before I go to bed. I just lather them up with this stuff that I have. And right now, since I have that week off, my feet are fine. There's a little bit of peeling, but what I had the last time was even in between my toes. It was kind of disgusting actually. It was more an inconvenience at times because I wanted to go for a walk, but I couldn't because my feet were so sore. So that's probably one big side effect that I guess I didn't anticipate. But the best thing you can do is keep putting lotion on them because that makes it so the ulcers aren't†so tough and so hard to manage. So making sure that you make time to put some kind of skin softener or some kind of lotion on your feet.

Response.BaseQuestion: The medicine I use for the nausea works actually very, very well.
Response.Content: Nausea, I usually get that the first couple days that I'm on the drug and then it kind of goes away, but it's never gone completely.† I carry my anti-nausea drug with me all the time, so if by some chance I have that feeling, I pop one of these and hopefully it passes. And for the most part it does. The medicine I use for the nausea works actually very, very well.

Response.BaseQuestion: As soon as you start to feel some of those ulcers that you let your doc know.
Response.Content: Essentially, you get these ulcers all through your mouth and it was so disgusting. I couldn't drink; I couldn't eat anything. It was all in my mouth and down my throat. That was probably the worst side effect I've ever experienced, was this mucositis. Right now I'm using this liquid because I have a couple ulcers now, but nothing like I had before. So I have this other rinse that I take a Q-tip and just kind of coat the inside of my mouth with it. It really makes it a lot more tolerable. But if you start to get, what I didn't realize that was mucositis. I mean I read about it, I'd looked at books all this other kind of thing, but nobody told me that this was going to really kill your mouth and you're not going to be able to eat, so this was an area where I could have used a little more education. I didn't have it. I would recommend that as soon as you start to feel some of those ulcers that you let your doc know. If they have a nurse navigator or some type of nurse let them know early because I didn't know what was happening and I didn't tell anyone up front because I just thought it was a mouth sore and that would be it. So what I did for it was I had this rinse I had this almost like Lidocaine gel sort of that I would put on the inside of my mouth to try and help them heal. I also got these laser treatments all inside my mouth on each sides of my tongue, all the way, she would go this far but then that was it and that helped a lot. Really, really helped a lot, but I wish I would have known about those things much earlier because I think I would have started some of that stuff way before my mouth got so disgustingly gross.

Response.BaseQuestion: Even when I went to doctor's appointments I would write down who I saw, what, for instance the CAT scan was fine. They didn't see anything unusual. That's really been a big help.
Response.Content: I would strongly recommend people keep a journal or if you want, a word document on your computer or you know something you can reference back because and actually this was helpful in starting to write my book. I went back to the very beginning when I started when I was Initially sick, and I have all this stuff written down so that if I forgot something I could go back and look and say, "No, no, no I didn't start that drug until Friday or something like that." Very helpful. Even when I would go to doctor's appointments I would write down who I saw, what, for instance the CAT scan was fine. They didn't see anything unusual. That's really been a big help. Other than I now have 5 of these little notebooks filled with stuff. But it's very helpful. Now some people don't go back to the old paper and pencil anymore, so there are tons of apps out there. If you just go in and search. Well, you can start out searching for cancer and there are all kind of different ones out there. Again, trial and error, what works for you. I don't want to make more work for myself, so I try to use the app. If it's real complicated, forget it I'm not using it, but for something that makes a lot of sense then I actually use the app and it's been extremely helpful. Very, very helpful.

Response.BaseQuestion: You never know when you first start an oral chemo how it's going to affect you.
Response.Content: Some of the side effects I've dealt with from oral chemo mostly have to do with my digestion and my stomach whether it's happy or unhappy. Keeping it happy has always been kind of trial and error. You get told that you're going to have upset stomach or you're going to have diarrhea or you're going to have constipation and so you try it and you see. And so one night you're running out in the middle the night to buy Imodium, and the next they are running out the middle the night to buy you know MiraLAX. You never know when you first start an oral chemo how it's going to affect you. I can read the box. I am a smart girl. So I know often what to expect, but I don't know what I'm going to expect. Because although those drugs are great for the masses, it doesn't always mean it's going to be great for me.

Response.BaseQuestion: There have been times when my hands and feet hurt so bad that I didn't know what to do, and I've tried everything.
Response.Content: Another thing is that hand and foot, I don't know if they call it hand and foot disease or I†forget what they call it, but it's been funny I use it as an excuse not to do dishes. I tell my husband that I can't. "No, I can't wear rubber gloves either. I have to just not do dishes." He's going to know now that I can do dishes, but there have been times when my hands and feet hurt so bad that I didn't know what to do, and I've tried everything. You know Cataphyll and udder cream and just take Vaseline a pair of socks on and that will be just fine. I've tried all of those and not all them work. Some of them I think are just advertisements from the people that make the products because I've never had any relief, but you find ways around them. For instance, my hands would get really bad, really sensitive. I was always wearing gloves. Well I found fingerless gloves. Because I would type and I used to tell everybody at my old work that I was cold and it was keeping me warm. No, it wasn't that, it was protecting my hands; it was keeping my hands from hurting even worse and keeping them covered so it didn't get worse that night. Because there were a lot of times I would go home, and my hands and feet would hurt so bad that I'd have a hard time sleeping. The hands were always more obvious than my feet, and the hands used to be worse than my feet too. So I was always trying to protect my hands not getting them to cold or not to hot or anything like that. My feet, if I knew I was going out into snow I probably wouldn't have done it, because the pain that would have been associated with that afterwards would not have been worth it. But a lot of it came down to Vaseline. It made my feet nice and soft and I would just put on a pair of socks over it, which in turn helped me stay warm which is always a problem when of course you don't have any hair. But the Vaseline was probably the best bet I did.

Response.BaseQuestion: It has affected my hands mostly, which has been pretty frustrating because stupid things like putting on eyeliner have become very difficult for me.
Response.Content: Neuropathy can be really frustrating. I didn't experience it until probably six months ago, so I made it four years with no neuropathy. Everybody is, "How's the neuropathy" and I'm going, "What neuropathy" and I've had some pretty serious chemos. And I don't know why it has only just affected me. But it has affected my hands mostly, which has been pretty frustrating because stupid things like putting on eyeliner have become very difficult for me. Because I know they are there and I know what movement they need to go through, but I can't tell they are going through that movement. Does that sound fair? So, I'll be trying to pick something up and I'll think I have it, but I can't feel necessarily that I have it. So, I'm starting to get some of my feeling back in my hands which has been huge because I used to braid my kids hair left and right, you know braids every day. "Mom can you do this new kind of crazy braid?" "Sure." But I can't feel the strands, but I know I'm doing it right. So sometimes you have to have a little faith that what you are doing because of muscle memory still works even if you can't feel it ,you have to know it is still working. Predominately it's numbness, but every once in a while I'll have needles almost like my hand fell asleep, but I know it didn't because it never goes away. So mostly I deal with numbness. Mostly in my right hand. Mostly in my fingers, but it also keeps my right hand closed so where as if you just sat down however naturally your hands would sit my right hand closes up.

Response.BaseQuestion: A good portion of the time I'll hear it from the doctor and I'll go talk to the nurses because sometimes they are more informed about side effects or this will do that or whatever interaction I might have than the doctors will.
Response.Content: A good portion of the time I'll hear it from the doctor and I'll go talk to the nurses because sometimes they are more informed about side effects or this will do that or whatever interaction I might have than the doctors will. I get more from the relationship with my nurse than from my doctor. I understand that. I can understand that reasoning. He's so busy. He's trying to save peoples' lives and it's not just mine. But I have fantastic PA's that I don't call them doctor so and so. I call them Mary Anne. I call them Peg. I call them by their first name. Maybe I'm a different patient, maybe I'm more vocal than some, but I've made relationships with these people because I've got to find a way through this. I can't go in there and call my oncologist by his first name. He'd think I was crazy, but I do call his wife by her first name. I do know her and I'm in a support group with her and I can call her by the first name, but I can't call him. Everybody else, from the person that checks me in to the person that walks me back, I know all their names and I know something about all of them. But it allows me probably to be more human than my time with my oncologist because they know the answers. And sometimes you know, they'll sneak answers to me or they'll know something's bothering me and tell me a way around it or a great article. Like, I do give them back and forth, a lot of the information I have, but they also give me what they have. And sometimes together it works. Not always, but I would say it is hugely important.

Response.BaseQuestion: The first time I lost it I was devastated. Let's just be honest. I was 33 I had only been married 8 years.
Response.Content: The first time I lost it I was devastated. Let's just be honest. I was 33 I had only been married 8 years. What is my husband going to think about it? What are my kids going to think about it? What is my work going to think about it? I can't afford a wig. There are just so many things that go through your head. So shaved my head and I covered my head with wigs and everything else the first time. I was very cognizant of how other people were going to view me. I honestly believe my husband loves me no matter what. For my daughters, I was losing my hair by the handful. I let them dye it. It was a little blue, it was a little pink, and it was a little purple. Because you know what it was going to fall out, so go ahead. It only lasted for about a day because I was losing it that fast. My husband taught them how to use clippers. He the first time used to shave my head all the time. I'd be like, "It's getting a little crazy over here can you fix that?" He'd be like, "bzzzzz," because he did his own. This time with my kids we let them all shave my head. I wore a wig for the first week. I wore it here, I wore it to work. I even wore it to Texas where it was super-duper hot for a site we did, and I was a big sweaty mess. You should have seen me trying to figure out how take the head through security. Because I did, because I had such a complex like I had to put it on the head and I had to brush it and I had to do the hair. I didn't even do my hair when I had hair. So after about a week I said forget this. I started to wear a head cover that actually somebody here recommended. And at the time I couldn't afford them. They were expensive and super cute and I told my mom about them well what did my mom do, but go buy a couple? So then I could actually, instead of wearing the same head cover that I'd been wearing for four and a half years, I'm not even kidding, I now had four new ones that I could wear. Well my hair grew in and I started to every once in a while to show people the new me, my new head. I've gotten, "Well you're lucky you've got a good shaped head," or, "You're lucky your hair is all coming in consistently," or any kind of possible things. Mostly positive nobody's ever said anything bad to me, but I've said to my kids, if you need me to I'll put my wig on. If you want me to pick you up at school with my wig on, if you want me to go to parent teacher conference with my wig on, I don't care just tell me. Let's be honest. Let's be open. Nope I like you like this. My five year old will fall asleep rubbing my head. I've caught my husband every once in awhile rubbing my head. It's like, we'll get you a dog because that's about what it feels like. I go everywhere bald. Except when I'm freezing then I'll wear a head wrap. I've given up and just said, "You know this is just what it is." Part of me wants to make it platinum, or red, or black, but then I think then it's going to grow in and I'm going to have to dye it again. I'm more bugged by my eyebrows and my eyelashes cause those ones you lose too. When you get a hair losing chemo you lose you eyebrows and eyelashes too. And without those to frame your face, I wear my glasses a lot more because I think it just gives me a frame. So the first time I had pin straight, like middle of my back hair, and I would grow it out every pregnancy and then donate it. I had done that 3 times and so I thought I was going to have this pin straight hair well no it came back in curly and it was super curly to the point where I would have these curls that would come right next to my head and I'd try to be pinning them back and id try to be pin the hair behind my ears. I was trying to figure all that out. But definitely I experienced a different consistency.

Response.BaseQuestion: Understand what your rights are, and you do have rights and what your options are.
Response.Content: So what I would encourage people to do is to do some research at home. Understand what your rights are, and you do have rights and what your options are. You can go to a situation where you can work part time or you can reduce your work schedule or you can go on a short-term disability or you can go under social security. I have always been able, since my metastatic diagnosis, I have been able to go on disability, but I would not be the person I am today if I went on disability. I have to come here, and I have to talk to people, I have to interact and do all those things, so that is not the right option for everybody. I would learn at home on my own, and then I would approach my HR department. I would choose my allies carefully in my cancer battle in my work, because some works are going to just rally behind you and they're going to make it worth it, but some aren't. And I don't think we really know which one they are going to end up being until they're in that position.

Response.BaseQuestion: When I got home and started seeing some of the side effects and I thought oh my goodness this is going to be bad, so what did I do? I called my oncologist.
Response.Content: I was given this handy dandy little bag. You're all going to know which drug I was on, but this bag. And in it, it had Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday. AM, PM. It had my little insert, and it had some things that could help me, dietitional stuff, and all kinds of stuff and they are like, "here you go" the drug will show up in a week. And your like, "I guess I'll go read it." So then you read it and you have no idea what half of it is. You read what you can and understand what you can, but so much of it is medical terminology that unless you're a nurse or doctor that you don't necessarily get. But that is all they give you, but I took the time and I sat and I read it, and I also didn't blindly just follow the directions. When I got home and started seeing some of the side effects and I thought. "Oh my goodness this is going to be bad, so what did I do?" I called my oncologist. Actually I texted or emailed him and he emails me back in the middle of the night and I said. "There has got to be an alternative to this drug it sounds awful, this is kind of scaring me. What else can I do instead of this drug?" It's probably the question that has gotten me through the last two and a half years. "That sounds terrible, what else can I do instead of that." He was like, "No, it looks scary, but it's not going to be scary. So you go home and try it." After the first week you're like, "I'm still ok." After the second week you're like, "I'm still okay." And the third week comes and you go, "Well my hand is kind of bothering me, but I'm still okay. Okay this is going to work. I'm going to take this one."

Response.BaseQuestion: And that's what it comes down to. Is that if I can get this drug more reasonably then I'll take the drug maybe I'll live a little bit longer and my family isn't in debt yet. Yet.
Response.Content: Now I'm onto my third set of paperwork to get their approval to give me a drug that is out there. It's just whether or not my health care will cover it. And I've gone as far as having to give my tax returns for last year before they will agree to give me a drug discounted. Because sometimes you may get a drug and you may say, "I really have to have this drug and I'm going to spend 5,000 dollars a month on this drug." And that's okay. If that's what you have to do to get treatment and to be healthy, then that's what you do. But in my case I'm battling if I make too much money, if I don't make enough money like I'm kind of amazed by it. It's amazing what they'll ask you. Like I said, household income, what, why do you need my household income? But that is because they are asking, obviously I got approved on some level but at some very high rate so of course my doctor's office is trying to combat this really high rate and they're trying to prove that I need it and I need it at a discounted rate. So there's a lot going on right now. It's probably been about two and a half weeks and it still hasn't been approved. From the time my oncologist first told me about it he's, "Oh there's alternatives but they have these awful side effects. This drug works and we know it works and people have a decent quality of life on it." So I'm like, "I'm all in." I've done the research and I've read about it. I've found the same thing he did that the alternatives have negative side effects. But yeah right now the oncologist office is trying to get it for me so it's a little bit more reasonable. Right now the one that I have not been officially approved for will be 3,000 dollars and it will be 3 pills a day for 30 days. So, 90 pills 3,000 dollars. And I have good insurance, very good insurance. And I look and I say, "I have three little girls. One is about to be 10, ones about to be 8 and one is four. And would I rather die without them being in debt or take this drug?" And that's what it comes down to. Is that if I can get this drug more reasonably then I'll take the drug, maybe I'll live a little bit longer, and my family isn't in debt yet. Yet. Because some of the drugs get very expensive and that is why we're are still battling. It's funny, you know I talk to the people here at the office and they're like, "Who can we call?" Well that is a very good question. I don't know. Is there somebody you can call? Is there somebody anyone of us average Joes can call not through health care? Do they care? Are they going to take our call? I don't know that answer.

Response.BaseQuestion: I've explained to them it will make you sick so it is not something anybody can take.
Response.Content: I would just put it on the very top shelf. I told the kids it was there because I don't want hide something from them and have them catch me trying to sneak something out of the, because then it will be to alluring and they'll try to climb it and get it themselves. But I explained to them that I really don't want you guys touching this but this is what keeps mommy's cancer sleeping. So I need to have this drug, but I want you guys to know this is what I take so they're not trying to climb and take it themselves. I've explained to them it will make you sick.

Response.BaseQuestion: It's very hard to take oral chemo because you know you are going to get sick. It's hard to have those pills in your hand and know you don't want to take them
Response.Content: I think because my sister works in a pharmacy that I'm really kind of crazy about the oral adherence kind of stuff. Also, because I believe in chemo and I don't think I'm going to heal miraculously. It's very hard to take oral chemo because you know you are going to get sick. It's hard to have those pills in your hand and know you don't want to take them. You don't want the side effects that are coming out of those little pills. The reality is your body needs it and you've got to take them. There are a lot of people I know that don't, and there are a lot of people that don't follow schedules. There are a lot of people that miss a dose. I wouldn't. I would take it with me. I'm pretty conscientious about that stuff.

Response.BaseQuestion: You can go online, but most of the time they have a board like that you can go on and read other people that are dealing with ABC drug and what side effects they are dealing with.
Response.Content: If you find you are going to be on drug ABC, you can get the information from your doctor, your nurses all those things. You can go online, but most of the time they have a board like that you can go on and read other people that are dealing with ABC drug and what side effects they are dealing with. I was telling my friend, my tongue always hangs to the left, and that's a joke. It really doesn't. But how did you know that could be a side effect, that your tongue could hang to the left? It's this crazy thing. Well, because I read it on a board and it didn't just happen to one person. I actually had that with a bone drug that I had. It was giving me the worst side effect which was just my mental well-being was not good. And I thought I was going crazy because I was feeling crazy. But I couldn't prove that I was doing this and I went on some of the boards and there it was and multiple times. That this drug causes this effect for people but it wasn't in any of the printed material and it wasn't anything my doctor or nurses had dealt with, but it was something that was on the boards that came related to that drug.

Response.BaseQuestion: There are some days, I'm not going to make it, I'm going to take one of these pills and I'm going to just zone out for a little bit. That's okay because everybody needs a mental break.
Response.Content: Cancer is not easy to deal with because you didn't ask for it. Were you at home licking asbestos? Probably not. Was this a surprise? Did this come out of the blue? Absolutely. But sometimes you got to figure out other ways to get around it. I know a lot of people use yoga and all this stuff, not for me. I'd rather spend the time with my kids. But what I do is I imagine a box and I put my cancer in that box, and I wrap that box up and I put the box up on a shelf. And I bring it down when I need to talk about it, when I'm upset about it, when something changes and I deal with it and I cry and I'm mad and I'm sometimes mean because I didn't deserve this. I didn't ask for this. But then I promptly put the lid back on and I wrap it back up and I put it back on that shelf and I go back to being a mom. I go back to being a wife. I go back to being an employee. I go back to those things that help me not think about cancer. And I've been pretty fortunate that I don't have to take a lot of stuff. I know there are a lot of people that do and I totally understand that. There are some days where I am like, "I'm not going to make it and I'm going to take one of these pills and I'm going to just zone out for a little bit." And that's okay because everybody needs a mental break. I don't care if you have cancer or not. I've got three kids and cancer and there are sometimes that I think about it. I'll just take one every day, but it is not the right choice, and I have found that the box works for me.

Response.BaseQuestion: You can't really flush them down the toilet because what it is doing to you it's going to do the plants and animals.
Response.Content: So I had some left over and I thought, "Just take it back to chemo. Hi, I have this. What do I do with this?" "Oh, we don't take it." "Well, what do I do with this?" "Well, you take it back to a pharmacy." "Okay great." So I went back to my pharmacy and I said, "Hi, I need to return this." "We can't take that and they handed me an envelope and they said you take this envelope and you mail it back." I said, "Great, I'll look at this. Wait, you are going to charge me shipping?" I had to pay shipping to send it back. But I ended up going through my neighborhood grocery store that gave me a thing that I had to pay to ship back and I stuck it in there and shipped it back. And I've heard you can sometimes take them to like a firehouse, police station and stuff like that. I've never had to do that, but I've seen places that you could do that and then you don't have to at least pay the shipping and I'm sure it's a lot more convenient. You can't really flush them down the toilet because what it is doing to you it's going to do the plants and animals that it eventually is going to run into. It's going to make our water treatment facilities work even harder to kind of manage and get back to a normal levels, so no you can't really go throw all your chemo in your toilet. It is just not preferred.

Response.BaseQuestion: It's going to remind you that, yeah cancer is there, but you're not dead.
Response.Content: Just holding my husband's hand can be enough. Like, sometimes you're doing chemo and you're fighting, you're just fighting at every turn. You're going to fight to go to work. You're going to fight to go to your kid's baseball game. You're going to fight to feel well enough to go to that movie with your girlfriend. And it is a constant battle. And there are sometimes that you just need that emotional, physical reminder that there is somebody there in your corner. I'm very lucky. I have a fantastic husband. I don't know what I did without him because he's a great dad, he's a great husband, and he's a great person. Before I got married my mother said, "You know your husband is going to want to have sex and you're not, but you're going to have sex because that's what your husband wants. But there's going to be, as many times you want to have sex where your husband doesn't, but he's going to have sex because it's what you want. There are going to be times when you don't want to and you're going to because it's going to be the right thing in your marriage, in your home behind your closed doors with your husband. It's the right thing to do for the two of you and there are going to be times you don't want to do it, but you're going to figure it out." And she says, my mom, my mom's a handful, and she'll be like, "I guarantee two minutes later you're going to like it. You're going to have fun. Because it's going to remind you that, yeah cancer is there, but you're not dead." Like, I have a terrible, awful cancer and it's pulling me apart piece by piece, but I'm not dead.
